dialogues.speaker: THE HOSPITAL. 6
dialogues.text: A cold newly-dawned sun shines down on the vast sprawling complex of the hospital. Desultory early morning traffic First Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: The night shift of nurses is closing out another night's  work, which has been on the whole uneventful. The head nu MRS. REARDON, hunches over her paperwork. NURSE ELIZABETH RIVERS sits at the desk beside her, resting her head on t palm of one hand. NURSE'S AID J.C. MILLER crosses with an armful of linens. She disappears into the pharmacy and su areas behind the Nurses' Station. In the west corridor, N LUCINDA PEREZ glances at her watch, then pads down to Roo 806. She enters.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806. DAY
dialogues.text: A cold gray light cheerlessly illuminates the room. Nurse Perez checks the I.V. on the comatose patient who is in t bed nearest the door. Then she turns to regard the other which gives her pause. NURSE'S P.O.V.: Intern Dr. Schaefer is lying on this bed, rigid, eyes dilated, pupils staring unseeing. An I.V. tub sticks out of his naked right arm. Nurse Perez doesn't qu know what to make of the fact that Dr. Schaefer is lying that bed with an I.V. tube sticking out of him looking de Frowning, she reaches out a tentative hand to shake his n shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Schaefer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is, of course, no response. A terrible suspicion en Nurse Perez's mind, and she closes her eyes and sighs a l shuddering sigh. Then she opens her eyes and, with a seco and briefer sigh, reaches for Schaefer's neck to take his pulse. Clearly, the result is not encouraging. She sighs  another short sigh and regards Schaefer's unblinking, dil pupils. It's all a bit too much for her; she shuffles to window and stares out into the gray morning where things a little more comprehensible. Once again, she returns to bed, regards Schaefer's death mask. She raises the bedshe and, for one short but appreciative moment, considers  Schaefer's naked body. She lets the bedsheet carefully do She sighs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying again, with  little hope) Doctor Schaefer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sighs, turns and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Nurse Perez, frowning and pursing her lips, moves slowly  back to...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: Head Nurse Reardon is still bent over her paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, did you know Doctor Schaefer  was in Eight-O-Six, because he's  dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (late forties,  continues her  painstaking paperwork,  grunts) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just telling you, Dr. Schaefer  is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (works on; after a  moment, looks up) What do you want, Perez?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't know what the hell  this is all about, but Dr. Schaefer  is in Room 806 with an I.V. running  and he's dead. I didn't even know he  was sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regards Perez a moment) Perez, what the hell are you talking  about? (appeals to Nurse  Rivers coming out of  the floor pharmacy) Do you know what the hell she's  talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I'm going crazy. I don't  know. Isn't Room 806 the patient  Guernsey? I mean, did something happen  I don't know about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perez, I don't know what you're  talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the nuttiest thing I ever  saw. Dr. Schaefer's in Room 806 dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Dr. Schaefer? Our Dr. Schaefer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Dr. Schaefer. The one who's always  grabbing everybody's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nurse Rivers) Do you know what she's talking about?  I don't know what she's talking about. (to Perez) What do you mean Doctor Schaefer's  in Room 806 dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, he's lying on the far bed,  stone dead, and with an I.V. tube  sticking out of him. And if you don't  believe me, maybe you just ought to  get up and look for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a short, irritable sigh, Mrs. Reardon abandons her  paperwork and heads down the west corridor, followed by N Perez and Rivers. CAMERA TRACKS as Mrs. Reardon turns to  Nurse Rivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, maybe you'd better call  Mrs. Christie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S HOTEL ROOM
dialogues.text: Dark. Venetian blinds drawn. TV set on, a gray coarse-gra square. PHONE RINGS. DR. HERBERT BOCK, 53 years old, a large man, bulky,  disheveled, apparently fell asleep in a chair while watch television the night before. The bed still has its spread but is rumpled. Bock is in trousers and shirt, collar ope barefooted. PHONE RINGS. The reading lamp is the only lig in the room except for the sheen of gray hissing from the television. Newspapers litter the floor. Books, two-day-o plates of food, yesterday's mugs of coffee, cigar-stuffed ashtrays, a shirt, a pair of pants, a winter overcoat, a  battered gray fedora have been slung about. PHONE on the  bedtable RINGS again, begins to penetrate the sotted slee of the man. Two bottles of booze, one empty, and a clump glasses are on the coffee table in front of Bock. He grun opens an eye. PHONE RINGS. Bock suddenly exsufflates in a snorting grunt. He stands, shuffles to the bed, a big, so fellow, picks up the receiver, interrupting its next RING He sinks, sitting on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Bock... Yes, Mrs.  Christie, what is it? It's all right,  I'd be getting up in a few minutes  anyway... I'm sorry I missed that.  Would you say it again? Yes, I know  him, Schaefer, the stud with the  glasses, who fancies the nurses...  I'm afraid I don't understand that,  what do you mean? Was he sick? I  mean, was he... uh, what was the  cause of death? Was he being treated?  I don't understand. What was he doing  in the bed? You did say he... Look,  Mrs. Christie, did you call the  office? Good, well, I'll... No, no,  it's all right. I'll be getting my  wake-up call any minute anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns the receiver to its cradle, sits disoriented,  unbuttoning his shirt. HOSPITAL. MORNING. 8:00 A.M. LONG SHOT of the hospital, now alive and jumping. Taxis p up and out of the large U-shaped drive. A noisy picket li of about twenty chanting protesters parade with signs in uneven ellipse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chanting) Two-four! Help the poor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the placards are slogan-y: "PEOPLE YES! DOCTORS N "CURE POVERTY! HEAL THE POOR!" Two protesters move toward the street, waving and yelling at an approaching car. One young white fellow wears a sandwich board that goes into matter at some length: "WE PROTEST THE EVICTION OF 386 BL

dialogues.speaker: EXPANSIONIST POLICIES OF THIS IMPERIALIST HOSPITAL."
dialogues.text: In the back seat of the car sits JOHN SUNDSTROM, handsome graying, tanned, early fifties, the Director of the Hospi He looks up. That young demonstrator, DR. IVES, a sandy-h bespectacled man of 30 in a white doctor's coat, sidles t the car's open rear window angrily shouting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, Sundstrom? How much  longer do you think our monopolistic,  exclusionary, racist policies will  work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're the hope!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sundstrom lowers his window and gives his driver directio He exits in the BACKGROUND parking area, where he notices Bock emerging from his car. Sundstrom waits for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how's it going, Herb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock's sour glance says it all. He locks his car, joins  Sundstrom, and the two men start down the concrete ramp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) One of my interns dropped dead this  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? I'm sorry to hear that. I  understand you've moved out to a  hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It got that bad with Phyllis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been that bad for twenty-four  years. Are you going to be solicitous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They trudge across the U-shaped entrance drive, pausing t let a car pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Herb, I'm the guy who brought  you into this hospital, so I think I  can skip the diplomatic overtures.  Marty stopped me in the hall  yesterday, very upset. He had just  had lunch with you and said you  sounded suicidal. Marty tends to be  extravagant, but he's not the only  one. Jack Singer mentioned the other  day you've been boozing it up a lot.  And let's face it, you've been  sloughing off. I understand you  haven't even been doing rounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to do rounds today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick their way around the shuffling line of proteste many with Afro haircuts and tinted glasses, including a b minister and four young white activists.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL, HOLLY PAVILION, EXECUTIVE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Early-arriving secretaries chat in the doorways. The corr itself connects to the Bryce Pavilion (pediatrics, gyneco and obstetrics), so a steady stream of traffic moves back and forth. Bock and Sundstrom enter the corridor and slow a halt to continue their chat by a wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herb, want a couple of days off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go down to Montego Bay, get drunk,  get laid, get a little sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, John, I'm fifty-three  years old with all the attendant  fears. I just left my wife after  twenty-four years. Standard case of  menopausal melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you ought to have a talk with  Joe Einhorn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to see a psychiatrist.  Stop worrying about me. All I have  to do is get my ass back to work,  and I'll be fine. I'm sorry I've  caused you concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets off down the long corridor to the elevators. MILT MEAD, the Administrator of the Hospital, comes out of one the offices, waves a good morning to Bock, who acknowledg him and plods on. Mead comes up to Sundstrom, now moving  toward his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid just called from St. Luke's, and  he's heard that the demonstrators up  there are planning a march to join  the bunch down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God. (he wraps his arm  around Mead's  shoulders, ushering  him into his office  area) Did you call the cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR. 8
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens. Out comes Bock, overcoat unbutto now. He clumps to the Nurses' Station. An unusual number nurses seems to be there. Through the doorway of the floo pharmacy, we can see Nurse Rivers of the night shift bein comforted by Nurse Perez of the night shift and Nurse Edw of the morning shift. The head morning nurse, MRS. DONOVA is at the desk hunched over her paperwork. (Nurses are al hunched over their paperwork.) NURSE FELICIA CHILE is als seated at the desk doing some paperwork. Head Nurse Donov looks up briefly as Dr. Bock approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to her paperwork) They're all in Eight-O-Six, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll just let Mrs. Christie  tell you about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock lumbers off for the west corridor through a press of activity. Kitchen workers trundle creaking portable carts nurse's aids and attendants pop in and out of doorways be trays and used dishes. A robed patient or two ambulates a the hall. Morning rounds have just started, which means a clump of white-jacketed, white-trousered young doctors ar gathered in a gaggle at the far end. The group includes s resident MONROE BRUBAKER, junior resident HARVEY BIEGELMA interns SAM CHANDLER and IRVING AMBLER and another medica student, all lounging outside a door discussing the condi of the patient within. Chandler is presenting the case from a handful of notecar in his hand. The others lean against the walls, listening They wear shirts and ties with the exception of Ambler, w is new to the floor and still in the canonical white tuni under his jacket. They are all in their twenties and have swinger sideburns and occasional mustaches. When he spots Dr. Bock, senior resident Brubaker turns the rounds over Biegelman and joins Bock just outside 806.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he approaches,  rolls his eyes) Oh boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen some pretty good snafus,  but this one... I mean, there's a  certain splendor to this one. One of  the night nurses, a float, thought  Schaefer was a patient and plugged  an I.V. into him. He was a diabetic,  you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, a nurse plugged an  I.V. into him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's really a screwed-up story,  Doctor. You see, what happened was  we had an old man in that bed who  died last night, so the bed was  available. And you know Schaefer.  He's Sammy Stud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he talked a nurse into zapping  him on that bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was a girl from hematology  he's been running with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, it's a Roman farce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to Room 806 opens, and an Assistant Administrato named HITCHCOCK pokes his head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I heard you out here,  Doctor. (he too rolls his  eyes heavenward in  an expression of  incredulity)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock makes a noise and goes into...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: Aside from Hitchcock, the room includes MRS. CHRISTIE, th Director of Nurses, a fusty forty-six, in streetclothes;  Head Night Nurse, Mrs. Reardon, in uniform; Head Evening  Nurse, MRS. DUNNE, mid-fifties, who had apparently been c in from home because she's in mufti and wearing a winter  coat; and, of course, the comatose patient and the dead D Schaefer. Mrs. Christie is instructing the two nurses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need one from both of you, three  copies, and I suggest you do that  right now. The forms are in my  office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dunne, on the verge of tears, head bobbing, looks up Bock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really so terribly sorry about  this, Dr. Bock. I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regarding Schaefer's  rigid death mask) As I understand it, one of the nurses  inadvertently administered an I.V.  to Schaefer here. How the hell could  that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I think we ought to straighten  this out somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, very good idea. Oh God, what a  mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all file out now, Bock in the rear into...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY, NURSES' STATION AND LOBBY AREA
dialogues.text: They all go along to the Nurses' Station where Mrs. Reard and Mrs. Dunne disappear into the rooms behind. Mrs. Chri leads Hitchcock and the trailing Bock to the TV-solarium; but Dr. Brubaker is now holding his rounds there. He stan quietly expounding on the uses of heparin, a decoagulant. One of the patients last night had hemorrhaged consequent injudicious use of that drug. Listening, the other young  doctors make notes. Mrs. Christie leans against the wall. Apparently, the conference is to take place in the corrid Background activity continues normally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sigh) Well, these things happen, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I'd better call the Medical  Examiner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it took an hour to get it sorted  out. It seems a patient named Guernsey  died last night in Eight-O-Six, but  that information wasn't given to the  night nurses. These things happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock has begun to get the drift. A curious state of apath settles over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattling on) At any rate, according to the cardex,  the patient Guernsey was down for  twenty-five milligrams of Sparine Q- 6-H, so Mrs. Reardon sent Nurse Perez  to give him his twelve o'clock shot.  Meanwhile, it seems Dr. Schaefer had  usurped that particular bed for his  own purposes. Dr. Brubaker suggests  it was for a love tryst, and some  weight is given that hypothesis by  the fact that Dr. Schaefer was naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to give his  attention to this) I get the drift, Mrs. Christie. In  other words, Nurse Perez went in and  sedated Dr. Schaefer thinking it was  the patient Guernsey. My God! What I  don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may finish, Doctor. Well, after  Perez gave him his shot, she noticed  the I.V. on the bed had been pinched  off, and she reported that back to  Mrs. Reardon, who then assigned Nurse  Rivers to restart the I.V. (Bock sighs) Now Rivers was a float. She didn't  even know the staff people on the  floor, and nobody knew what the  patient Guernsey looked like anyway,  since he'd only been admitted that  morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So she plugged an I.V. into him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A liter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (The doctor in him  intrudes into his  lassitude) A five percent glucose solution won't  kill anybody. Did he have any other  ancillary conditions? He wasn't  dehydrated, was he? Didn't anybody  bother to go in to check him during  the night, even under the impression  he was merely a patient? Was he  hyperasthmolic? Did he have a bad  heart? He must have had some kind of  thrombosis. I want the post done  here, Mr. Hitchcock. And you and I  better have a little chat, Mrs.  Christie, about your excessive use  of float nurses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got nearly a thousand nurses in  this hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering rage) And every time one of them has her  period, she disappears for three  days. My doctors complain regularly  they can't find the same nurse on  the same floor two days in a row.  What the hell am I supposed to tell  that boy Schaefer's parents? That a  substitute nurse assassinated him,  because she couldn't tell the doctors  from the patients on the floor? My  God, the incompetence here is  absolutely radiant! I mean, two  separate nurses walk into a room,  stick needles into a man -- and one  of those was a number eighteen jelco! --  tourniquet the poor sonofabitch,  anchor the poor sonofabitch's arm  with adhesive tape, and it's the  wrong poor sonofabitch! I mean, my  God! Where do you train your nurses,  Mrs. Christie? Dachau!? (he is aware his voice  has risen and is  attracting attention.  He lowers his voice) All right, wrap him up and get him  down to Pathology. I'm especially  interested in his blood sugar. A  liter of glucose never killed anybody.  Your ladies must've done something  else to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will there be anything else, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you call the family, Doctor,  I wish you'd talk to Mr. Mead about  this. We'd like, naturally, to avoid  litigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock heads abruptly down the corridor to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, SEVENTH FLOOR, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: A corridor of offices. This is the Department of Medicine where Bock and all the senior staff members of the depart have their offices. It's quiet, since most of the staff a away at their various specialties about the hospital. Bock comes up the corridor still wearing the overcoat he  arrived in some hours ago. He has only managed to unbutto it in all the time it has taken him to reach the corner  office. Gilt lettering on the door reads: DEPARTMENT OF  MEDICINE and below that DR. HERBERT E. BOCK.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE, OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Small office with two desks. As Department Chief, Bock ge two secretaries. Both are at their desks, one on the phon MISS GLORIA LEBOW, and the other rattling away on the IBM MISS STEPHANIE McGUIRE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouthing) Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would seem not. Bock waves a listless hand, exits into

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S PRIVATE OFFICE
dialogues.text: The modestly imposing office is lined with medical tomes. Bock slips out of his coat and jacket and hangs them in t closet. In shirtsleeves with his tie a bit askew --  fastidiousness in dress is not Bock's strong point -- he  crosses to his desk and sits, breathing more heavily than his small exertions would seem to warrant. He seems exhau There is a KNOCK on the door. Miss Lebow enters, holding filing envelope stuffed with papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few things have been piling up.  Would you like to go into them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guttural noise indicates yes. Miss Lebow pulls up a cha opens her folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quickie. Dr. Esterhazy wants to  start hiring temporary people to  cover the summer vacations. He says  last year some of the replacement  people didn't receive their checks  until they waited six months. He  wonders if you could do something  about getting these people paid more  promptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She places a sheet of paper on the desk in front of Bock. tries to give his attention to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drones on) Miss Aronovici complains the lab  reports are coming in slow into the  E.R. I called Dr. Immelman about  that, and she said three microscopes  have been stolen out of her lab in  the last two months. Charley Waters  also complains about pilferage. I've  clumped all those together for you... (she lays a sheaf of  memos in front of  Bock, who stares at  them blankly) Now, as you know, Doctor, we've agreed  to take over the local ambulance  cases as part of the hospital's  commitment to the community, and  it's created a serious overload in  the E.R. I don't know why this was  dumped in our lap, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock obviously isn't up to all this. He waves a limp hand stop Miss Lebow's morning report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at his desktop) Find out if Dr. Einhorn is in his  office yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which Dr. Einhorn? Ophthalmology or  Psychiatry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Psychiatry. (suddenly stands) Never mind. I'll look in myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lumbers across the room and out into...

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: ...and down past Miss McGuire, rattling away on her IBM, out into...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, SEVENTH FLOOR, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...down past several closed doors, stopping at a door mar DEPARTMENT OF PSYCHIATRY, DR. JOSEPH EINHORN. He enters.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EINHORN'S OFFICE, SECRETARY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: A secretary at her desk, sips coffee and reads a paperbac novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor is obviously in. He can be seen through the op door sitting at his desk writing in a notebook. Bock lean in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you give me a few minutes, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (short, chunky,  bespectacled, late  fifties) Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock goes in, closes the door behind himself.

dialogues.speaker: DR. EINHORN'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Bock looks only at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ill at ease) I've been having periods of acute  depression recently. Apparently,  it's becoming noticeable. A number  of people have remarked on it. Anyway,  John Sundstrom thought it might be a  good idea if I spoke to you about  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to sit down, Herb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not good at confessional. (he ambles around) Well, what can I tell you? The last  year, two, three... it goes way back,  I suppose. I can remember entertaining  suicidal thoughts as a college  student. At any rate, I've always  found life demanding. I'm an only  child of lower-middle-class people.  I was the glory of my parents. My  son the doctor. Well, you know. I  was always top of my class.  Scholarship to Harvard. The boy  genius, the brilliant eccentric.  Terrified of women, clumsy at sports.  God, Joe, how the hell do I go about  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you just separated from  your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left her a dozen times. She left  me a dozen times. We stayed together  through a process of attrition.  Obviously sado-masochistic dependency.  My home is hell. We've got a twenty- three-year-old boy I threw out of  the house last year. A shaggy-haired  Maoist. I don't know where he is,  presumably building bombs in basements  as an expression of his universal  brotherhood. I've got a seventeen- year-old daughter who's had two  abortions in two years and got  arrested last week at a rock festival  for pushing drugs. They let her off.  The typical affluent American family.  I don't mean to be facile about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, he does not. He is horrified by the fact his eyes are wet and he is verging on tears. He turns away quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I blame myself for those two useless  young people. I never exercised  parental authority. I'm no good at  that. Oh, God, I'm no good at this  either. Joe, let's just forget the  whole thing. I'm sorry I bothered  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How serious are your suicidal  speculations, Herb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door) I amuse myself with different ways  of killing myself that don't look  like suicide. I wouldn't want to do  my family out of the insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Digitalis will give you an arrhythmia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A good toxologist would find traces.  Potassium's much better. Sixty milli  equivalent. Instantaneous. Of course,  then you're stuck with how to get  rid of the hypodermic. Forty milli  equivalent. Gives you plenty of time  to dispose of the evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to have given considerable  thought to the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to know a man who talks  about it all the time never does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I see a man who's  exhausted, emotionally drained,  riddled with guilt, and has been  systematically stripping himself of  his wife, children, friends, isolating  himself from the world. Are you  impotent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intermittently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means I haven't tried in so long,  I don't know. Let's just drop the  whole thing, Joe. I feel humiliated  and stupid. All I have to do is pull  myself together and get back into my  work. I'm sorry I troubled you. Take  care of yourself. I'll see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Einhorn can say a word, he slips away and disappea into his own office. HOLLY PAVILION. 8:30 A.M. The score of protesters outside the pavilion still move i an uneven ellipse and shout: "Two -- Four! Help the Poor! Ives, the bespectacled demonstrator who shouted at Sundst earlier, is removing his sandwich boards and giving them his replacement. He hurries across the walk and into...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, LOBBY
dialogues.text: Ives cuts through the congestion of people and moves swif up the long corridor leading to the Farkis Building,  unbuttoning his overcoat as he goes into...

dialogues.speaker: THE FARKIS BUILDING, FIFTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: ...and comes out, as the elevator opens. This is a labora floor, and the corridors are empty except for a white- uniformed orderly leaning against a wall and for one youn woman in a white smock in the background, who waves to th young man before disappearing into one of the rooms. Ives fishes out a ring of keys and unlocks the door to his own lab. He enters into...

dialogues.speaker: FARKIS BUILDING, NEPHROLOGY LAB
dialogues.text: Dingy and cheerless place, as labs go. Ives hangs his coa in the cupboard, loosens his tie, unbuttons his suit jack squats on a stool, reaches over for a loose file on the w table, opens the file and begins to read the papers insid A door CLICKS open behind him, and without looking up, he waves briefly to whoever has entered. CAMERA DOLLIES to F SHOT of Ives frowning over his notes. We are suddenly  conscious of a white-uniformed presence behind him. We kn it's medical personnel, but we can't see the face. Ives s to turn to the presence behind him, when suddenly a small hospital sandbag is whipped down on his head, and he slum forward, his forehead thumping against the black surface the lab table.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL. NOON
dialogues.text: HIGH ANGLE SHOT establishing the passing of hours. Sun hi overhead, traffic on First Avenue an impenetrable river o HONKS and HOOTS. At a crosswalk, a loose procession of fi or so shouting demonstrators, bearing placards, flows tow the main gates. Their posters read: "FIGHT DOPE -- NOT DO "DRUGS YES! TRANSPLANTS NO!" and "SAVE OUR KIDS FROM THE  SKIDS!" which is what they now chant: "Save our kids! Fro the Skids!" The demonstration moves through a handful of  city cops where our original group of twenty still ramble around, chanting: "Two -- Four! Help the Poor!"

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: The staff elevator doors open and Bock comes out, wearing his long white doctor's coat unbuttoned. Hanging about th Nurses' Station are Dr. Brubaker and a few young men in w They come quickly to respectful attention at Bock's entra CLATTERING TRAYS dominate the lunchtime atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All set?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctors move off toward the solarium on the east corr overlooking the river. They pass a curious quartet of peo consisting of a very handsome YOUNG WOMAN in her late twe in an out-of-fashion miniskirt (She has great legs, long tanned.); an ELDERLY MAN, uncomfortable in city clothes a unmistakably an INDIAN; a tall overcoated man in his fort wearing a MINISTER's white collar; and a DISTINGUISHED MA dressed in fashionable gray who is trying to persuade the young woman of something. The young woman and the Indian  stand absolutely still, silent, impassive. The minister i more fidgety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brubaker en passant) Who's that exotic group?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs) You got me. They've been here about  an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're with the old man in  Eight-O-Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock and Brubaker, trailed by young doctors, move into th TV room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Perry said he picked the  tuberculosis and the liver nodes for  today, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Because that's the one I studied  up. A hell of a case.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, TV ROOM
dialogues.text: Some twenty-five or thirty young doctors, two or three of them black, three or four of them women, fill the room. A Bock's entrance, they find places around the walls, sofas soft chairs and benches. The TV set has been pushed into corner, and a large portable blackboard has been set up.  This is the Chief of Service Round, attended by every  available intern and resident. Somebody closes the door,  just as two young doctors come hurrying in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, who's presenting?

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY AREA, WAITING ROOM
dialogues.text: People of all ages sit around on aluminum chairs arranged around the walls of the room. All are in streetclothes. S speak to each other. A line of people, extending into the hallway and holding their charts, waits for a lady from t accounting department taking Blue Cross numbers. This lad from accounting is MRS. CUSHING, late forties, bespectacl and testy. She calls out at large.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anybody seated who hasn't  been to see me first? Is there anyone  here who hasn't given me their health  insurance number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her phone RINGS. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency Room... Well, I don't know,  Sybil. What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a man on line at her desk, thrusting his chart out to  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you wait a moment, please. I'm  on the phone, can't you see I'm on  the phone? (rummaging through a  stack of charts,  large paper forms in  quadruplicate) ...Of course not, do they ever? (hangs up, takes two  charts from the desk,  pushes through the  waiting line) Would you mind, please. I have to  get through, do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes her way to the door and goes out into...

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY AREA, ENTRANCE LOBBY
dialogues.text: ...which is congested. Mrs. Cushing enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Give me that one again... thirty- two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Facing the desk are six curtained treatment rooms, mostly open to view. Behind the desk are a supply room and anoth treatment room. Both are occupied, the former by a PARANO LADY wringing her hands in a paranoid rush and listened t by a very patient young intern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow me everywhere. Three big  black men. Naked, completely exposed.  Right in the street. Hanging down to  their knees. Disgusting. They're  waiting out there for me now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and in the other room, a man in his thirties is being  treated for some sort of head lacerations. In one treatme room, the Chief of Emergency Service, DR. SPEZIO, a man i his late thirties, along with an intern, an anesthesiolog and a nurse, is bent over a naked and comatose young blac woman of eighteen, covered somewhat with a sheet. She's a junkie, being intubated, i.e. a small endotracheal tube h been inserted into her mouth. This is the most melodramat of the varied activity here. A middle-aged man complaining of chest pains is lying clo in another treatment room; a nurse attends him. An asthmatic middle-aged woman sits in still another room being administered her 500 mg. of amenophylene subcutaneo The curtains on another room are drawn for privacy. On ch in the corner sit a teenage boy with a badly sprained ank and an elderly man bathing his hand in an enamel basin he in his lap. A young mother with a five-year-old daughter with a badly cut arm is being attended to by the back wall. The Emerge Room Nursing Supervisor, MISS ARONOVICI, a pretty woman i her mid-twenties, is sterilizing the little girl's wound. Mrs. Cushing makes her way to Miss Aronovici. They detest each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you call upstairs and tell them  to admit a patient named Mitgang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing to treat  the little girl) The concussion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. They just called me.  They said you didn't fill out the  chart. And where do you come off  sending anyone up to Admitting without  my okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Aronovici turns to Mrs. Cushing, regarding her sweet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally, would you get the fuck out of  here. The patient's in the Holding  Room. You want his Blue Cross number,  you go in and you get his Blue Cross  number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cushing elbows back through the line of patients wai at the Admitting desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are now three nurses behind the desk, all of them o phones. One nurse calls to Dr. Spezio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.P.D. wants to know how that  asthmatic they sent down is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (just leaving the  group around the  junkie) She's fine. We'd like to keep her  here a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spezio heads for the door where he is intercepted by Mrs. Cushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I see you a moment, Doctor, if  you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, calls back to  the triage nurse) I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes out, followed by Mrs. Cushing, into...

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY AREA, LOBBY
dialogues.text: Spezio and Mrs. Cushing move between laundry and supply c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrusting some papers  at the doctor) If you don't mind, Doctor, is this  your handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spezio stops, sighs, examines the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to read that? Was it a  sprain? Was it a broken wrist? I  can't read that scribbling. I mean,  I have to bill these people. I know  you doctors are the ministering  angels, and I'm just the bitch from  the Accounting Department, but I  have my job to do too. I mean, if  you don't mind, Doctor...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studies the paper) The kid had a collar fracture. We  had him in the O.R. We reduced it  and we gave him a small cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calls after him) But did you give him a sling? You  must have taken X-rays. How am I  supposed to make up the charges?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns into...

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY AREA, HOLDING ROOM
dialogues.text: Designed to hold patients who've been examined and wait t be admitted to a room upstairs, it's in fact used for  examination, treatment, storage. The room is quiet. Two m patients lie on comfortable stretchers, apparently sedate and resting. Mrs. Cushing turns to the patient immediatel to her right as she enters. To the still figure she poses her questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Mitgang?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets no answer from that bed. From another direction, voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mitgang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to Mitgang. Something bothers her about the fir patient. She finds Mitgang's chart tucked in under his pi takes out her pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you carry Blue Cross, Blue Shield,  Mr. Mitgang, if you don't mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitgang, eyes closed, emits a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have your card with you? (no answer) Do you know your number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negative grunt from Mitgang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Mitgang, you're not leaving this  room until I have this information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enters for some chore) Will you leave that man alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a fit of temper, Mrs. Cushing throws the chart and her pencil down on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating the other  patient) Do you mind if I at least ask this  gentleman to fill out his chart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls his chart from under his pillow, bends and retr her pencil from the floor, straightens. She speaks to the silent patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have your A.H.S. policy number,  sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on the patient. We now  recognize him as the bespectacled young activist Dr. Ives so recently coshed over the head with a sandbag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looming) Do you carry Blue Cross? Blue Shield?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Cushing stares at the patient. He is not breathing.  Behind her, the nurse exits carrying whatever she came fo Mrs. Cushing turns to her, but she is gone. Frowning, Mrs Cushing backs out... ...as Dr. Spezio and others come down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Spezio approaches,  with spiteful relish) I think one of your patients in here  is dead, Dr. Spezio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enters the Holding  Room) Why do you say that, Mrs. Cushing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he wouldn't give me his Blue  Cross number, Dr. Spezio.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDING ROOM
dialogues.text: Spezio regards the death mask of a face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves quickly forward to raise the dead man's eyelid.  Behind him, a nurse enters. He wheels on her angrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell long has this man been  lying here? Isn't this that doctor  who came in around nine o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: MILTON MEAD'S OFFICE. 2
dialogues.text: MILTON MEAD, late thirties, lean, efficient but under con strain, is having his daily staff luncheon conference, wh consists of a CHIEF ENGINEER, the ASSISTANT ADMINISTRATOR PERSONNEL, three residents in administration, including  Hitchcock, sandwiches and coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, they gave me a hard time,  Con Ed. "For Pete's Sake," I said,  "this is a hospital. One of our  feedlines just blew..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mead's phone RINGS and he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? (it's another  annoyance; he sighs  with irritation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it's lucky we traced it in  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) No, I'll be right up. (hangs up, stands) Have we covered about everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Kish has been driving me nuts  with the O.R. schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's supposed to see me about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves across his office into...

dialogues.speaker: MEAD'S SECRETARY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Actually a communal office with desks for three secretari

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks up to Mead  from talking on the  phone) This is the Emergency Room. One of  the doctors just died of a heart  attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauses) One of our staff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mead frowns, leans back into his own office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hitchcock) Tom, you want to go down to the  Emergency Room? One of our doctors  just died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Another one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, see what that's about. (en passant to  secretary) I'll be on Holly Eight. I'll be right  back.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: The staff elevator door opens, and Milton Mead comes out. has apparently been buttonholed in the elevator by a woma in a doctor's coat, DR. IMMELMAN, Pathology, who follows out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no longer pilferage, Milton.  It's reached the point of piracy.  That's the third microscope this  month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we get together on this  sometime this afternoon, Fran?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One o'clock will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns left and heads for...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR, NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: ...where Head Nurse Donovan is bent over her paperwork. I the background, we see normal morning hospital activity.  Nurse's Aid, SHARLENE STONE, takes towels into a room. R. Felicia Chile comes out of another, bearing her enamel tr of instruments. Also in the background, the curious quartet from before - the beautiful woman, the elderly Indian, the minister, Dr Sutcliffe. Mead hardly notices them as he makes for the d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without pausing or  looking up) Your brother's in the room, Mr. Mead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What room is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-O-Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mead bobs his head thank you and heads for the west corri

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, ROOM
dialogues.text: As Milton Mead enters, his elder brother, WILLIAM MEAD, m forties, a smaller and manifestly nervous man, is seated  sullenly puffing a cigar, fidgeting, still wearing his co and hat. He looks up briefly when Milton enters and avoid his brother's eye. His wife, MARILYN, late thirties, is  standing in suppressed exasperation, staring out the wind Out of respect for the COMATOSE PATIENT, the ensuing agit scene is held in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake, Willie, you're  going to be in the hospital for two  lousy days. What're you making such  a fuss about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be such a big  wheel here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no private rooms available.  If they brought in Jesus Christ fresh  off the cross, I couldn't get Him a  private room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to stay in a room with  a dying man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not dying. They'll screen him  off. You won't even know he's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want a private room, go on  home, and I'll call you the first  one that comes up. But you're the  one who phoned me in a panic, you're  going on a vacation. For heaven's  sake, Willie, they'll cut this polyp  out tomorrow morning. You'll be home  Thursday, you'll be in Miami Friday.  Marilyn, will you talk some sense  into this lunatic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you said it, he's a lunatic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big wheel, can't even get me a private  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get you a tranquilizer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, TV ROOM
dialogues.text: Bock -- excited, vivid, alive -- is in full flush with hi lecture. He moves around in front of the blackboard, chal in hand. The blackboard itself is scrawled with formulae diagrams. He is writing the words "full abdomen," as the  fifth in a list reading "(1) parexia, (2) hepatomegaly, ( splenomegaly, (4) episodes of arthralgia." The audience i forty young doctors rapt with attention. There is a good  deal of note-taking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...five, a full abdomen contrasted  to wasting elsewhere; six, ascites  with a protein content above four  grams; unexplained anemia, leukopenia,  unexplained elevation of the serum  gamma globulin level, especially  abnormal flocculation tests, and of  course, a positive P.P.D. All these  findings assume special significance  among Negroes. This has been a very  commendable workup, as commendable a  workup of an F.U.O. as I can remember.  The staff of this floor is to be  applauded. (spots Brubaker among  the others) It's a reportable case, Brubaker.  Write it up. (a brief, rare smile) Well, let's go have a look at the  girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rumbles toward the door. The class of doctors dissolve into hospital murmurs and mutters and a general dispersal They follow Bock out to...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, EAST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...where Dr. Sutfcliffe, the beautiful young woman, the  elderly Indian and the minister are engaged in agitated  discussion. The girl and the Indian retain their stoic  impassivity. Dr. Sutcliffe leaves them and moves down the corridor to the counter of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse! Nurse, who's the Senior  Resident on this floor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be Dr. Brubaker. But I'm  afraid he's at Chief of Service rounds  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sutcliffe points off right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's... this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse nods indifferently. ACROSS to Bock coming out of the TV room, followed by som dozen young doctors. Bock is in very good spirits indeed. quizzes his young doctors en route:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if there might not be some  correlation between hepatic  tuberculosis and drug addiction.  Presumably, there was an early  consideration of S.B.E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Yes, sir. We discounted it after  repeated blood cultures were negative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, Ambler. Is that right, Ambler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else do you look for in bacterial  endocarditis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) Some sort of embolic phenomena, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flagging Brubaker) Dr. Brubaker, I wonder if I could  see you for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brubaker detaches himself from his group to join Sutcliff CAMERA STAYS with Bock and his entourage, following them  down the east corridor, Bock still happily conducting cla Bock strides into...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 819
dialogues.text: Past two beds, they group around the foot of a third bed the right side of the room. Bock checks the patient lying the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still a little icteric. Who's got an  opthalmoscope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the young men hands his to Bock, who leans over th patient to look through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did anyone note Roth spots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctors exchange a look as Bock rises, moves toward t laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't worry about it. There  aren't any. Ambler, you're our big  man on S.B.E. What was the latex- fixation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't done, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think that's an important  test to differentiate S.B.E. from  miliary T.B.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) No, s...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not you, Biegelman. Ambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's about a seventy percent  incidence of false-positive latex in  S.B.E.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock hands the opthalmoscope to Ambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been reading up. If the  diagnosis were S.B.E., would a  positive latex indicate anything in  the therapy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd expect the latex to become  negative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the antibiotic therapy were  successful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you applying for your internship  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and see me. (to the patient,  helping her up) Would you sit up for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock turns to the off-screen patient, helping her sit up forward, percussing her back as the students look on.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, EAST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Brubaker and Sutcliffe are now both involved in discussio with the woman, the Indian and the minister, as Bock drif through the background, followed by the band of young doc now dispersing. Bock crosses past the foreground group to the staff elevator. He pushes the button. Brubaker approa Bock. They confer quietly in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got a little thing over here,  Doctor. The girl over there is the  daughter of the patient in Eight-O- Six. He is at the moment comatose  and requires intravenous feeding and  meds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator comes and goes, disgorging some, taking on  others. Bock, who greeted Brubaker with a rare, benign sm has begun to look a bit sodden. Poor Brubaker, aware of t gathering storm in Bock's demeanor, sighs and continues  regardless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The thing is, the daughter wants to  take the father out of the hospital  and back to Mexico where they live.  The patient's name is Drummond. He's  apparently a Methodist missionary,  and he and his daughter run some  kind of religious mission among the  Apache Indians. The daughter claims  to be a licensed nurse, so she can  give the necessary I.V. treatment. I  certainly don't think he should be  let out of this hospital. The  Attending -- he's the guy in gray  over there -- concurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock squints at Brubaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, wait a minute. Let me  have all that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, Doctor, this is  Dr. Biegelman's case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind the professional ethics,  what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) I don't know why I'm covering for  that sonofabitch in Farkis Pavilion  anyway. (sighs and begins) The patient, a man of fifty-six, was  admitted to the hospital ten days  ago for a check-up, in good health,  no visible distress. We did the  mandatory work-up on him. Blood  cultures, stool, L.E. preps, chest,  E.K.G., all negative. But there was  apparently some evidence of protein  in his urine. I don't know how that  sonofabitch in Farkis Pavilion ever  found out about it. Maybe he had  some kind of deal with one of the  girls in the lab. Anyway, he turned  up the next day, conned the patient  into signing an authorization for a  biopsy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sonofabitch in Farkis Pavilion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some post-grad fellow named Ives.  Elroy Ives. I never met him. He's on  one of the immunology research  programs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me some post- grad fellow came up here and did a  biopsy on the patient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. He conned Biegelman with  that old story about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...protein in the urine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he biopsied the man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he nicked a vessel, and at two  o'clock in the morning, they woke up  Biegelman because the nurse found  the patient in shock. Biegelman called  the kidney people for a consult right  away. What was there to see? The man  was sour and bleeding. We spoke to  this fellow Sutcliffe, and he referred  us to a surgeon named Welbeck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welbeck?! That barber!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't heard nothing yet. So we  finally got Welbeck around four in  the morning. He said, go ahead. So  they laid on the surgery for eight.  Welbeck turns up, half-stoned, orders  an I.V.P., clears him for allergies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...without actually testing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the patient went into shock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and tubular necrosis. They lopped  out the bleeding kidney, ran him  back to the room, and we sat around  waiting for three days to see how  obstructed he was. Fever began spiking  like hell, euremia, vomiting, so we  arranged hemodialysis. He's putting  out good water now. But some nurse  goofed on his last treatment. A leak  in the tube, something. His blood  pressure plunged. They ran him right  up to I.C.U., checked out vital signs,  all normal except he's comatose.  That was two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In short, a man came into this  hospital in perfectly good health,  and, in the space of one week, we  chopped out one kidney, damaged the  other, reduced him to coma and damn  near killed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great sad serenity has settled over Bock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Brubaker, last night I sat  in my hotel room, reviewing the  shambles of my life and contemplating  suicide. Then I said "No, Bock, don't  do it. You're a doctor, a healer.  You're the Chief of Medicine at one  of the great hospitals of the world.  You're a necessary person. Your life  is meaningful." Then I came in this  morning and find out one of my doctors  was killed by a couple of nurses who  mistook him for a patient because he  screwed a technician from the  nephrology lab...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hematology, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now you come to me with this  gothic horror story in which the  entire machinery of modern medicine  has apparently conspired to destroy  one lousy patient. How am I to sustain  my feeling of meaningfulness in the  face of this? You know, Brubaker, if  there was an oven around, I'd stick  my head in it. What was the name of  that sonofabitch from Farkis Pavilion  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ives, sir. Elroy Ives. Somebody ought  to ream his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gathering storm erupts. Rage suffuses Bock's face. Ou of respect for the hospital corridor and the people worki around him and Brubaker, he keeps it glacial. But there i no mistaking the volcanic fury he feels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely containing  himself) I'm going to ream his ass. And I'm  going to break that barber Welbeck's  back. I'm going to defrock those two  cannibals. They won't practice in my  hospital, I'll tell you that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll I tell the girl, sir? She  says we have no legal right to stop  her from taking her father out. She's  willing to sign an A.O.R. form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him go. Before we kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens. A couple of nurses come out. Boc strides in.

dialogues.speaker: SEVENTH FLOOR, DEPT. OF MEDICINE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Bock advances in a cold fury down to his office. He wrenc the door open.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE, OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Miss Lebow and Miss McGuire clatter away at typewriters.  Sitting on a chair in the crowded office is a senior staf doctor, a man in his late forties, wearing a coat similar Bock's. He is DR. LAGERMAN. He looks up from the magazine he's been leafing through as Bock storms in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Herb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock acknowledges him with a brusque nod, storms over to  Miss Lebow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Dr. Gilley. Put him on page  if you have to. I want to talk to  him right now. I don't care if he's  operating. (wheels around to  Miss McGuire) And you get me some monkey named  Ives. Ives. I-V-E-S, first name Elroy.  He's in the Farkis Pavilion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to talk to you, Joe. Would  you mind coming into my office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides, followed by Dr. Lagerman, into...

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S PRIVATE OFFICE
dialogues.text: ...and slams the door shut behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got some punk named Ives  rotating in your department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Herb...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sits at his desk) I also want to know what the hell  kind of a dialysis room you're  running. I just came from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone RINGS. Bock seizes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... Gilley? Put him on. Bock.  Didn't you tell me a couple of months  ago you were going to cut off all  privileges for that assassin, Welbeck?  Yeah. Wellbeck. He just butchered  another one of my patients... Oh,  come on, Harry! The man's a buccaneer!  I want him brought before the Medical  Executive Committee... He's in your  department, Harry, not mine. He's  putatively a surgeon!... I'll be  here! (slams receiver down,  stares at Lagerman) Listen, Joe, I think you should know  that you've got a research guy in  your department named Ives who's  been doing some very dubious biopsies.  We're having enough trouble squeezing  grants out of the Nixon  administration...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ives is dead, Herb. That's why I'm  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gives Bock pause. He blinks at Lagerman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Ives is dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean he's dead. He had a heart  attack in the Emergency Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a heart attack in the Emergency  Room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blinking) What the hell is this? Some kind of  plague? (stands) Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were just taking him down to  Pathology.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, FIRST FLOOR, PATHOLOGY DEPT
dialogues.text: Bock, Lagerman and Hitchcock have gathered across the shr figure of Dr. Ives on a stretcher. We are in the lab sect of Pathology; in the background, through the glass part o the door separating the lab from the surgery room, we can see the autopsy on Dr. Schaefer being performed. Schaefer's naked white cadaver is stretched out on an  operating table. He has been opened up and all his vital  organs are being excised. It's bloody. The autopsy is bei performed by DR. BREWSTER, the Resident in Pathology, dre in surgical scrub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the next thing anybody knew,  about three hours later, Mrs. Cushing  from Accounting came in and said  there was a dead man in the Holding  Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't find anything grotesque  about all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, at half past eight this  morning, we meet over a doctor who's  been killed intravenously, and here  we are again, four hours later, with  another doctor who had a heart attack  in the Emergency Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what're you suggesting Doctor?  Do you think we have a mad killer  stalking the halls of the hospital?  Presumably, Dr. Ives died of a heart  attack and Schaefer in a diabetic  coma. People do die of these things.  It's all perhaps coincidental, but I  don't think I'd call it grotesque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long are they going to be on  Schaefer's post?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knocks on the glass window of the door separating the  laboratory from the operating room. Dr. Brewster turns fr his gory chore. Bock makes a gesture saying, "How much  longer?" Brewster raises ten blood-drenched rubber-gloved fingers. Bock turns and shuffles across the lab for the d out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauses at door, to  Lagerman) I don't suppose you'd like to call  next of kin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deeply depressed) Oh God, I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes down...

dialogues.speaker: THE PATHOLOGY CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...and is soon lost in the normal traffic of the area.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOSPITAL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: CRASH of THUNDER. CRACKLE of LIGHTNING. A horror-film  rainstorm lashes the vast dark complex of buildings.

dialogues.speaker: SEVENTH FLOOR, DEPT. OF MEDICINE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Dark, empty, silent. One lonely light at the lobby end of the long, closed corridor of offices. The door to Bock's  office stands ajar and issues a trace of light.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: ACROSS the silent, dark, typewriter-covered desks of the secretaries through the doorway to Bock's private office, can see Bock at his desk, lit by the desk lamp. He has a  bottle of booze on his desk. He gets up from his desk. He has made a decision.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: The corridors are silent; the night lights are on, subdue Head Evening Nurse Mrs. Dunne is back at her desk, hunche over paperwork. Resident Brubaker passes by.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, PHARMACY
dialogues.text: Nurse SHERLEE DEVINE, a black woman in her mid-twenties, a porcelain tray on the shelf onto which she puts a small jar of alcohol, cotton swabs, a wrapped hypodermic needle and syringe. She moves out into...

dialogues.speaker: NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: ...where Mrs. Dunne looks up as she passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dunne nods. Nurse Devine makes her way silently down the sleeping doors to...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: Dark, sleeping. The bathroom light is on, but only a thin stream of yellow light trickles through the door. THUNDER CRASHES. William Mead sleeps fitfully. The other patient entirely curtained off. Nurse Devine sets her tray on Mea bedtable, turns on the goose-neck lamp, keeping it from h eyes. She unwraps the hypodermic syringe, sets in the nee draws the required dosage, reaches over and gently shakes Mead by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Mr. Mead... Mr. Mead, I have an  injection for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mead sleeps on. Expressionlessly, Nurse Devine extracts M right arm from under the sheets, wets a swab with alcohol and rubs down the vein. The needle slides into Mead's vei OVER THIS, we begin to hear a distant sibilant HISSING,  indistinct like the leakage of a bad heart. There is also occasional distinctly human but not quite civilized sound CAMERA PULLS BACK SLOWLY to Nurse Devine withdrawing the  needle, looking up, for she too has heard the soft, stran sounds. They emanate from behind the curtains of the othe bed. Nurse Devine returns the syringe to the tray, gather her things and pads silently around Mead's bed to Drummon bed. With her free hand, she opens the curtains a little stares in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on in there?

dialogues.speaker: APPEASE THE SPIRIT OF THE THUNDER.
dialogues.text: The old Indian has stripped to the waist and marked his b with smears of dye and tule pollen. He wears a ceremonial hat, a sort of beaded beanie. He holds a small buckskin b of pollen in his cupped palms and is facing north, east,  south and west, offering the bag and prayers under his br as he does. A beaded amulet lies stretched across the whi sheet covering the comatose Drummond. When Nurse Devine draws the curtains, Barbara frowns at N Devine, holds a cautioning finger to her lips and draws t curtains closed again. Nurse Devine, carrying her porcela tray, exits.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: Bock comes out of the elevator, jacketed now, fairly drun but holding it well. He heads for the Nurses' Station as Nurse Devine comes do the west corridor. Bock grunts at Mrs. Dunne and goes int

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACY
dialogues.text: ...where he quickly runs his finger along the second shel until he comes to the bottle of potassium which he filche off the shelf and slips into his pocket. He rummages thro the drawers for a hypodermic syringe. Through the open  doorway, we see Nurse Devine making her way swiftly up to Mrs. Dunne at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, honey, we got a witch-doctor  in Eight-O-Six, and you better go in  there. You know that Indian that was  sitting in Eight-O-Six all night?  He's still there, and the girl's  there, and they're doing some voodoo  in there, and I ain't kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Mrs. Dunne, Bock appears in the doorway to the pha where he stands listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean that Indian's in there, half- naked and going pis-pis-pis with a  little bag. You just better get in  there, Mrs. Dunne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dunne, annoyed, gets up and heads for the west corri followed by Nurse Devine and by an intrigued Dr. Bock at few paces behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to NURSE WEITZENBAUM,  coming out of another  room) You want to see somethin', baby? You  jus' come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the small procession bears down, Barbara Drummond slip out of that room to intercept them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (keeping her voice  low) Look, it's a perfectly harmless  ceremony, nothing to get excited  about. It'll be over in a few minutes  anyway. Mr. Blacktree is a shaman  who gets his power from the thunder,  and it's imperative he conclude his  rituals while the storm is still  going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visiting hours were over at nine  o'clock, Miss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock reaches for the door to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that's going on in there, Doctor,  is a simple Apache prayer for my  father's recovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock makes a vague noise, neither contradicting her nor  assenting, and continues around her into...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: As Bock slides in, a bit of the corridor light comes in w him. The curtains have been left sufficiently open to rev Mr. Blacktree. He is still stripped to the waist and mark with crosses of pollen. He extends two twigs to the four  directions after which he places the twigs carefully on t white sheet covering Drummond in a pattern around the amu already there. Behind Bock, Mrs. Dunne can be seen peekin in. The Indian is oblivious to both of them. Bock watches all with interest for a moment and then backs out into...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...closing the door after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The markings he's made on my father's  arms are from the pollen of the tule  plant. The twigs have no significance  other than they've been struck by  lightning and are consequently appeals  to the spirit of lightning. It's all  entirely harmless, a religious  ceremony, not a medical one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't seriously believe all that  mumbo-jumbo will cure him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, it won't kill  him, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They regard each other levelly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunts) Okay. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels and clumps off for the stairway exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Weitzenbaum opens the door of the room and peeks in At the stairway exit, Bock pauses to look back at all the women in front of Room 806.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Drummond, are you still taking  your father out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I still have to arrange an  ambulance service. Is there a phone  around I could use?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock exits. Barbara edges past Weitzenbaum, who is still  peeking into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: Barbara comes in, gathers her coat and purse from a chair and moves to the Indian, now occupied with what seems to the rolling of a cigarette. The two exchange a brief dial in Apache. The old Indian nods. Barbara turns and exits,  taking Nurse Weitzenbaum out with her and closing the doo The room is dark and hushed again. Blacktree lights his  cigarette and "sends the smoke up," a ritual which consis of puffing smoke to each of the four directions, mutterin in Apache "May all be well" after each puff. CAMERA SLOWLY PANS to the other bed where William Mead sl fitfully. The Apache words and pis-pis-pis penetrate Mead drugged sleep. He opens one eyelid and stares glazedly at the dark air. The SOUNDS persist. Blacktree chooses this  moment to sidle out from behind the curtains and continue his ritual in the less-confined space at the head of  Drummond's bed. It's quite a sight for a nervous, sedated man to wake to.  Thunder RUMBLES and the rain SLASHES and sudden, savage STREAK of lightning illuminates it all. Mead figures it's all a bad dream and, after a moment of  dully regarding the odd spectacle, closes his one eye and goes back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE, OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Barbara Drummond comes in. Bock has apparently turned the lights on for her, but Bock himself is not immediately  visible. She looks through the half-open door to Bock's  private office, and there he is, staring blankly at the  bottle. Barbara starts to say something, thinks better of it, lays down her coat, and looking around, spots a Manha classified directory which she hauls up from its shelf an sets on Miss Lebow's desk. She sits, quickly flips throug the pages. Barbara flips through the directory. Bock is partially vi in the background at his desk. He sits soddenly. Barbara  finds what she wants, opens her purse and takes out two  airplane tickets. She dials. The CLICKING of the dial cat Bock's ear. He looks up for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello. I'd like to arrange an  ambulance for one-thirty tomorrow  afternoon... Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ACROSS Bock at his desk with Barbara partially vi at Miss Lebow's desk. All he can see are her great long t legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in background on  phone) ...Drummond, first name, Barbara.  I'll pay cash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock stands a little unsteadily and moves around his desk get a better look at those legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) No, you're to pick up my father,  Drummond, Edward, at the Manhattan  Medical Center, Holly Pavilion, Room  Eight-O-Six. It's a stretcher case.  I presume you provide the stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She senses Bock watching her, turns, smiles. She's a very beautiful girl. She returns to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's to be taken to American Airlines,  Yes... No... Kennedy Airport, Flight  Seven-Two-Nine to Yuma, Arizona.  I'll accompany the patient... Yes,  thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns the receiver to its cradle. When she looks up again, Bock is no longer there. She returns the flight ti to her purse, snaps it shut, stands and moves to the door enters a step into...

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Bock, back at his desk, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You believe in witchcraft, Miss  Drummond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in everything, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock drains his glass and pours her a hefty shot of bourb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the door suddenly) My father, you should know, was a  very successful doctor in Boston, a  member of the Harvard Medical Faculty.  He was a widower, and I was his only  child. He was not an especially  religious man, a sober Methodist.  One evening, seven years ago, he  attended a Pentecostal meeting in  the commons rooms at Harvard and  suddenly found himself speaking in  tongues. (she takes her drink  and crosses to the  sofa) That is to say, he suddenly sank to  his knees at the back of the room  and began to talk fluently in a  language which no one had ever heard  before. This sort of thing happens  frequently at Pentecostal meetings,  and they began to happen regularly  to my father.
