(she sits) It was not unusual to walk into our  home and find my father sitting in  his office, utterly serene and happily  speaking to the air in this strange  foreign tongue. I was, at that time  twenty years old and having my  obligatory affair with a minority  group, in my case a Hopi Indian, a  post-graduate fellow at Harvard doing  his doctorate in the aboriginal  languages of the Southwest. One day,  I brought the Indian boy home just  as my father was sinking to his knees  in the entrance foyer in one of his  trances. The Indian wheeled in his  tracks and said, "Well, I'll be a  sonofabitch." You see, my father was  speaking an Apache dialect, an obscure  dialect at that, spoken only by a  ragged band of unreconstructed Indians  who had rejected the reservation and  were living in total isolation in  the Sierra Madre Mountains of northern  Mexico. Well! What do you say to  that, Dr. Bock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has been staring  at her as if she  were insane) What the hell am I supposed to say  to that, Miss Drummond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara throws back her head and roars with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sitting here boozing and, all of  a sudden, you start telling me some  demented story about your father's  religious conversion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you miss the point, Doctor.  Not my father's conversion -- mine.  You see, I had been hitting the acid  pretty regularly at that time. I had  achieved a few minor sensory  deformities, some suicidal despairs,  but nothing as wild as fluency in an  obscure Apache dialect. I mean, like  wow, man! I mean, here was living  afflatus right before my eyes! Within  a week, my father had closed his  Beacon Hill practice and set out to  start a mission in the Mexican  mountains. And I turned in my S.D.S.  card and my crash helmet and followed  him. It was a disaster, at least for  me. My father had received the  revelation, not I. He stood gaunt on  a mountain slope and preached the  apocalypse to solemnly amused Indians.  I masturbated a great deal. We lived  in a grass wickiup and ate raw rabbit  and crushed pion nuts. It was  hideous. Within two months, I was  back in Boston, a hollow shell and  dizzy with dengue, disenchanted with  everything. I turned to austerity,  combed my hair tight and entered  nursing school. I became haggard,  driven and had shamelessly incestuous  dreams about my father. I took up  with some of the senior staff at the  hospital. One of them, a portly  psychiatrist, explained I was  generated by an unresolved lust for  my father. I apparently cracked up.  One day, they found me walking to  work naked and screaming obscenities.  There was talk of institutionalizing  me, so I packed a bag and went back  to my father in the Sierra Madre  Mountains. I've been there ever since.  That's three years. My father is, of  course, mad as a hatter. I watch  over him and have been curiously  content. You see, Doctor, I believe  in everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pauses, her story over. Throughout, Bock has been try to keep his glowering eye on the desktop. During her long narrative, he once seized the bottle and took a swig. Mos he is finding the experience murkily sensual. His glance  keeps darting out from under his brows to surreptitiously look at the beautiful long tanned legs; or, when she bend for the drink she set on the floor, to peer down the flap open scalloped neck of her dress; she is bra-less. She, on the other hand, has been crossing and uncrossing legs, bending, stretching, so that her short dress has ri up almost to her waist and is saved from utter exhibition only by the darkness of the shadows. She seems unaffected Bock's voyeuristic interest in her, but she is surely not unaware of it. It is hard to believe she is not courting attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what was that all about, Miss  Drummond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was obvious as hell. I'm  trying to tell you I have a thing  for middle-aged men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admire your candor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been admiring a lot more than  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock looks up, and they suddenly find their eyes locked. dark, dense air in the room fairly steams with incipient  sexuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks down again) You're wasting your time. I've been  impotent for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rubbish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a crash of his fist on the desktop, Bock stands; he in a drunken rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lurches about) What the hell's wrong with being  impotent? My God, you kids are more  hung up on sex than the Victorians!  I've got a son, twenty-three. I threw  him out of the house last year.  Pietistic little humbug. He preached  universal love and despised everyone.  He had a blanket contempt for the  middle class, even its decencies. He  detested my mother because she had  petit bourgeois pride in her son the  doctor. I cannot tell you how  brutishly he ignored that rather  good old lady. When she died, he  didn't even come to the funeral. He  thought the chapel service an  hypocrisy. His generation didn't  live with lies, he told me. "Everybody  lives with lies," I said. I grabbed  him by his poncho, dragged him the  full length of our seven-room  despicably affluent middle-class  apartment and flung him out. I haven't  seen him since. But do you know what  he said to me as he stood there on  that landing on the verge of tears.  He shrieked at me: "You old fink!  You can't even get it up anymore!"  That was it, you see. That was his  real revolution. It wasn't racism  and the oppressed poor and the war  in Vietnam. The ultimate American  societal sickness was a limp dingus.  Hah! (he lurches about,  laughing rustily) My God, if there is a despised and  misunderstood minority in this  country, it's us poor impotent  bastards. Well, I'm impotent and  proud of it! Impotence is beautiful,  baby! (he raises a militant  fist) Power to the Impotent! Right on,  baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Right on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stares drunkenly at  her) When I say impotent, I don't mean  merely limp. Disagreeable as it may  be for a woman, a man may sometimes  lust for other things, something  less transient than an erection,  some sense of permanent worth. That's  what medicine was for me, my reason  for being. When I was thirty-four,  Miss Drummond, I presented a paper  before the annual convention of the  Society of Clinical Investigation  that pioneered the whole goddam field  of immunology. A breakthrough! I'm  in all the textbooks. I happen to be  an eminent man, Miss Drummond. And  you want to know something, Miss  Drummond? I don't give a goddam.  When I say I'm impotent, I mean I've  lost even my desire for work, which  is a hell of a lot more primal a  passion than sex. I've lost my raison  d'etre, my purpose, the only thing I  ever truly loved. It's all rubbish  anyway. Transplants, antibodies, we  manufacture genes, we can produce  birth ectogenetically, we can  practically clone people like carrots,  and half the kids in this ghetto  haven't even been inoculated for  polio! We have assembled the most  enormous medical establishment ever  conceived, and people are sicker  than ever! We cure nothing! We heal  nothing! The whole goddam wretched  world is strangulating in front of  our eyes! That's what I mean when I  say impotent! You don't know what  the hell I'm talking about, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired, I'm terribly tired, Miss  Drummond. And I hurt, and I've got  nothing going for me anymore. Can  you understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then can you understand that the  only admissable matter left is death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He suspects he is going to cry and turns quickly away. He sits heavily and fights his tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds to me like a familiar case of  morbid menopause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's hard for me to take your  despair very seriously, Doctor. You  obviously enjoy it so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, bugger off. That's all I need  now, clinical insights. Some  cockamamie twenty-five-year-old...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...acidhead's going to reassure me  about menopause now. Look, I'd like  to be alone, so why don't you beat  it? Close the door and turn off the  lights on your way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both suddenly conscious of a third presence in t room. They look to the door where Mr. Blacktree, fully cl again and carrying his coat, is standing in the doorway.  Barbara uncrosses her long legs and stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing to the door) Mr. Blacktree disapproves of my  miniskirt, but it was the only thing  I had to come to the city with. Back  at the tribe, I wear ankle-length  buckskin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell. Just close the door and turn  off the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara regards his hunched form and, murmuring in Apache she exits, closing the door. In the subsequent hush, thun RUMBLES and CRASHES. Wind sweeps the rain against the win panes. The sounds go unheeded by Bock, still as marble. Slowly, raises his head and sighs and then fishes about in his ja pockets to bring out the bottle of potassium and syringe. takes off his jacket, rolling up his shirtsleeve, poking  about for the vein. He removes his trouser belt, which he ties tightly about his upper arm for a tourniquet. Now, h tears the wrapping of the syringe and fits the needle to Fiddling about in the pockets of his jacket, he finally f a crumpled pack of cigarettes. He lights one and returns the business of killing himself, puffing expressionlessly he does. Thunder RUMBLES and rain SLASHES. He carefully d just the right amount of potassium from the bottle to the syringe, peering at the procedure against the light of hi desk lamp. He sets the cigarette on the ashtray, switches the hypodermic to his right hand, holds his left arm rigi out under the light of the lamp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) What're you shooting, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns slowly to the doorway, his bare left arm still  rigidly extended, the belt dangling, the hypodermic clenc in his other hand. Barbara is perfectly framed in the doo He stares at her, slowly suffusing with the numb, blind,  total rage of the aborted suicide. The thunder CRASHES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely gets the words  out) Leave me alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She approaches the desk affably, turns the potassium arou to read the label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potassium. You take enough of this  stuff, it'll kill you, Doc. (moves toward the  couch) It occurred to me that I might have  read you wrong, that you really were  suicidal. So I came back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock's rage erupts. He crashes the hypodermic syringe dow shattering it. The potassium puddles on the wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hysterical rage) Who the hell asked you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves around the desk, a shambling bear of a man, a le belt dangling dementedly from his arm, tears coursing dow his cheeks. He advances on her in a stuperous shuffle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell asked you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She regards his lumbering approach with a faint, grotesqu sensual smile. He reaches with his naked left arm to the  neck of her dress and, with one savage wrench, rips her s naked, sobbing through hysterical tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me alone! Why the hell don't  you leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is on her, crushing her down into the shadows of the c ravenous at her neck and shoulders in a brutish assault,  sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you let me do it? Who the  hell asked you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout the scene, CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN through the  flesh and fury to an INTENSE TWO-SHOT of this terrified a of love. Then slowly over Bock's plunging shoulder to the woman's face. She gasps at the moment of penetration, the her lovely face slowly shapes into smiling serenity. Bock sobs; even in the shadows we can see the path of the tear on his cheek. ABRUPT SILENCE. OUTSIDE THE HOSPITAL, NIGHT. 4:00 A.M. The quiet, black streets glisten wetly in the puddles of  lamplight.

dialogues.speaker: THE STEINMETZ PAVILION, TENTH FLOOR
dialogues.text: The night shift is finishing up. THERESA CAMPANELLA, R.N. high-strung girl in her early twenties, stands at a water tap holding a glass and popping some pills in her mouth. the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll see you.

dialogues.speaker: TENTH FLOOR CORRIDOR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Campanella comes out of the Dialysis room, puts on her co and walks to...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION LOBBY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Campanella moves down the empty corridor. All the doors a closed now; only the overhead light in the background of corridor glows weakly. Campanella puts a cigarette in her mouth, pauses to look for matches; she hasn't any. Scowli with annoyance, she continues to the lobby and stops by a partially visible white-jacketed figure reading a newspap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a match, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes the matches, lights her cigarette, inhaling dee when he suddenly sandbags her from behind. She goes down.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE. DAYBREAK, WEDNESDAY
dialogues.text: Covered by Bock's overcoat, Barbara tosses and turns on t couch in a small nightmare. Through the windows comes the first gray wash of dawn. FULL SHOT of Barbara, awake and on one elbow on the verge of a scream. She looks around t room. It is dark, empty, silent. ACROSS Barbara looking through the door to the secretaria office. It is likewise dark, but suddenly the lights go o and, a moment later, Bock enters. He holds a container of coffee in each hand and has something white draped over h forearm. From under Bock's bulky coat, Barbara watches hi lumber to his desk, where he sets the containers of coffe down. He drops the whitish garment over the back of a cha and then sits. He hoists a bulging folder of corresponden from his filing tray and hunches to work, reading. After moment, he regards the silent figure on the couch across room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises, picks up the second container and white dress f the chair. She reaches out an arm for the coffee. Bock ho up -- a nurse's uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swiped this for you out of the  nurses' locker room. I'll make good  on your dress. I'm afraid it's torn  beyond repair. Buy yourself a new  one or, if you like, give me your  size and I'll send it on to you. But  I want to talk to you about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me about what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About your father. You really  shouldn't move him in his condition.  I just had a look at his chart.  There's no reason to presume brain  damage. You know as well as I you  can't predict anything in these  instances. He could pull out of that  coma at any time. I think you should  let him stay here. I'll personally  look after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has perched on the edge of the couch, and she rests he cheek against the long, bent curve of his back, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your way of saying you'd  like me to stay in town a few more  days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to look at her, smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that would be nice, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sips her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, Miss Drummond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect you can call me Barbara,  considering you ravished me three  times last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three times?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look at him, pretending he didn't  count. You were as puffed up as a  toad about it. Punched a couple of  holes in your crusade for universal  impotence, didn't it? I think we're  on a first name basis by now. I'll  call you Herb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's give your father a week,  Barbara, what do you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a frown darkens her  face) No, I don't want my father in this  hospital. I had a dream about this  hospital. (some of the terror  shows on her face) I dreamt this enormous starched white  tile building suddenly erupted like  a volcano, and all the patients,  doctors, nurses, attendants,  orderlies, the whole line staff, the  food service people, the aged, the  lame -- and you right in the middle --  were stampeding in one hideous  screaming suicidal mass into the  sea. (she stares at him  wide-eyed, reliving  the dream) I'm taking my father out of here --  and as quickly as I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other, she in terror, he with affectio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a real fruitcake, you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sets her coffee down on the couch and decides to wear Bock's overcoat rather than use it as a cover. She search for the sleeves. Bock assists her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let me put it this way. I love  you. I fancied you from the first  moment you came lumbering down that  hallway upstairs. I said to Mr.  Blacktree, "Who's that hulking bear  of a man?" The Apaches are reverential  about bears. They won't eat bear  meat; they never skin bears. Bear is  thought of as both benign and evil,  but very strong power. Men with bear  power are highly respected and are  frequently said to be great healers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By now she's standing, the overcoat reaching her toes. Sh looks down at Bock perched on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said to Mr. Blacktree, "That man  gets his power from the bear."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell. Now, look, do you have a hotel,  some sort of accommodations where  you can stay for a week or so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara reaches for her coffee, sips, moves around in her tent of a coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let me put it this way,  Herb. My father and I accept the  implacability of death. If he dies,  he dies, but I'm taking him out of  here and back to Mexico about one  o'clock this afternoon. I want you  to come with us, because I love you  and want children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Mexico sounds a little  too remote for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use you down there, you  know. There's a curiously high  incidence of T.B. And you'd be a  doctor again, Herb. You'd be necessary  again. If you love me, I don't see  what other choice you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, if I love you? I  raped you in a suicidal rage. How  did we get to love and children all  of a sudden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, for heaven's sake, Herb, I ought  to know if a man loves me or not.  You must have told me half a hundred  times last night you loved me. You  murmured it, shouted it; one time,  you opened the window and bellowed  it out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think those were more expressions  of gratitude than love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gratitude for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my God, for resurrecting  feelings of life in me I thought  dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my God, what do you think love  is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I love you, and you love me.  I'm not about to argue with so  relentless a romantic. Well, then,  since we have this great passion  going for us, I don't see why you  won't stay on here in New York for a  week or ten days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up to ten days now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as it takes for your father's  condition to improve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I've had these prophetic dreams  for seven nights. Seven is a sinister  number. The meaning of these dreams  is very clear, seven times as clear.  I am to get my father and you out of  this hospital before we are all  destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throws up his hands) You're certifiable! My God, half the  time you're a perfectly intelligent  young woman, and then suddenly you  turn into a goddam cabalist who  believes in dreams, witchcraft and  bear power! And I don't like the way  you dismiss my whole life as  unnecessary. I do a lot of healing  right here in Manhattan. I don't  have to go to Mexico for it. I also  teach. I send out eighty doctors a  year into the world, sometimes  inspirited, at least competent. I've  built up one of the best damned  departments of medicine in the world.  We've got a hell of a heart unit  here and a hell of a kidney group. A  lot of people come into this hospital  in big trouble, Miss Drummond, and  go out better for the experience. So  don't tell me how unnecessary I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who's been slipping  into the nurse's  uniform) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how come, eight hours ago, you  were trying to kill yourself with an  overdose of potassium?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This last in reference to Barbara crossing to the secreta office, zippering her uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering her coat  and purse) My hotel. I have to check out. Mr.  Blacktree doesn't speak any English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the connecting  doorway) Well, you're coming back, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. I have to settle the bill  here and pack my father. And I think  you need a few hours alone to make  your decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What decisions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a very tired and very damaged  man. You've had a hideous marriage  and I assume a few tacky affairs  along the way. You're understandably  reluctant to get involved again.  And, on top of that, here I am with  the preposterous idea you throw  everything up and go off with me to  some barren mountains of Mexico. It  sounds utterly mad, I know. On the  other hand, you obviously find this  world as desolate as I do. You did  try to kill yourself last night. So  that's it, Herb. Either me and the  mountains or the bottle of potassium.  I'll be back in an hour or so. I'll  be in my father's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slips into her coat and exits, as Bock looks after he thoughtfully, then turns back to his own office.

dialogues.speaker: BOCK'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: He shuffles around distractedly, not knowing how to artic the exuberance he feels. Suddenly, he opens the window, l out and bellows to the empty air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I love you! (softly) My God!

dialogues.speaker: FIRST AVENUE, CONSTRUCTION AREA. DAWN
dialogues.text: A construction sign fills the screen. It reads ON THIS

dialogues.speaker: A DRUG REHABILITATION COMMUNITY CENTER, TO BE COMPLETED I
dialogues.text: 1973. E.F. SCHLAGER & CO., CONTRACTORS. Suddenly, the comes crashing down into CAMERA. It has been wrenched off the wooden fence protecting the row of tenements and  brownstones being demolished. About a dozen young and lou militants have torn it down. CAMERA PANS to show the row of houses behind the fence, t of which have already been reduced to rubble; the others  have been boarded up. The demolition generators and crane are parked silently along the curb. In the dark of 5:00 A three black families, carrying children, and children car household effects, mattresses, pots, pans, bags of grocer etc., are repossessing the condemned buildings. FIRST AVENUE, CONSTRUCTION AREA. DAY, 10:00 A.M. Strong sun overhead. The street has been roped off, and p are all over the place. A sparse crowd of a hundred or so throng the sidestreets off First Avenue. Signs read, "Peo S, Doctors No." A Channel 11 mobile news crew, newspape photographers, and a radio newscaster are recording the  situation with desultory interest. A POLICE CAPTAIN stands in the middle of the cordoned str bullhorning the occupiers of the condemned brownstones, w can be seen through the broken windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I repeat. I'm asking you to come out  peacefully. These buildings are  condemned and unfit for habitation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece of brick arches down from the roof of a building cracks the street a few feet from the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, tries again) You people are possessing this  building illegally and in violation  of the law. I'm asking you to come  out peacefully...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, ENTRANCE LOBBY. DAY
dialogues.text: A small press conference is going on in a corner of the l Reporters cluster, and TV cameras surround the Press  Representative of the Hospital, a young woman in her thir named EVELYN BASSEY, who is trying to read a statement,  squinting under her mod glasses at the blaze of lights se up by the camera crews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) ...complete sympathy with the tenants.  So the hospital has assumed the  responsibility of finding 400 housing  units in good buildings. The hospital  wishes to point out that this  particular row of buildings on First  Avenue was condemned by the City  before the hospital acquired  ownership, and even then, only after  responsible leaders in the community  had approved the building of our new  drug rehabilitation center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explodes on the phone) Goddammit, Barry, I've got a dozen  community leaders waiting for me in  the library! We've been trying to  work out some kind of negotiable  formula for two years! And with no  help from you people in the Urban  Affairs Division, I might add!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. WELBECK appears in the doorway. He's in his fifties,  gray, distinguished and very tanned with terribly, terrib kindly old country doctor eyes. He wears a camel hair top He smiles benignly and twinkles at Sundstrom from one of leather chairs across the desk from the Director.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hardly notices Welbeck) And I'm not going to throw all that  down the drain because some cockamamie  activist group is show-boating for  the television cameras! You get those  people out of those buildings before  a wall collapses or a fire breaks  out and we've got a riot on our  hands!... Okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, sighs, turns to the man across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles, twinkles) Having your troubles, eh? Well, I  won't take much of your time. My  name's Welbeck. I've been associated  with this hospital for six years,  and, yesterday afternoon, Dr. Gilley  called me to say he was cutting off  my privileges at the hospital. Do  you know anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at his watch) It's news to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he sent the report on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll probably get it tomorrow. Report  on what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not sure myself. I did a  nephrectomy on a man about seven  days ago. Emergency, called in at  four in the morning. The man was  hemorrhaging, he'd gone sour...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welbeck, I'm terribly sorry, but I  do have this meeting. (crosses to the door) In any event, there's nothing I can  do about it. If Gilley wants to cut  your privileges, he's Chief of  Surgery, it's within his province.  You'll have to have the hearing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits, followed by Welbeck into the...

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR'S SUITE, SECRETARIES' OFFICES
dialogues.text: Buzzing now. Typewriters clicking. Phones ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a laparotomy laid on for this  morning. I assume I'll be allowed to  go through with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (huffing a little) I've been associated with this  hospital for six years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, Welbeck. It seems to me  I've had your name down here before  for something... (to his secretary en  passant) I'll be in the staff room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Welbeck pass out into the...

dialogues.speaker: EXECUTIVE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Flowing with a normal stream of traffic, Sundstrom and We turn right and head down to the last room of the corridor Something comes to him, and Sundstrom pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You're the fellow  with the Medicaid collecting business  who incorporated and went public,  right? I mean, something like that?  Milton Mead was telling me about you  just the other day. You're a whole  medical conglomerate. You've got a  Factoring service, a computerized  billing company, and a few proprietary  hospitals, a few nursing homes. Good  heavens, Welbeck, you shouldn't be  brought up before a committee of  mere doctors. You should be  investigated by the Securities and  Exchange Commission. You'll have to  go through with the hearing, Welbeck.  I don't interfere in these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the door of the staff room and strides in. Even  before he enters, we get a blast of angry voices, both ma and female. For the moment the door is ajar, we see a har Milton Mead being assailed by angry blacks and Puerto Ric and young white activist doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (all overlapping) ...no goddam halfway house, no way,  baby! We ain't gonna wait 'til 1973  to deal with this problem! We want  to kill the drug thing right now!...  imperializing the Blackaporican  community, and we reject the bourgie- ass middle-class black traitors and  flunkies who are selling out the  Blackaporican proletariat masses to  the expansionist, racist policies of  this shit hospital!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get back to the abortion issue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Woman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does the male  establishment know about abortions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an agitated reaction in the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell raised the issue of  birth control? The issue at hand is  the control of drug addiction in  this community and in the ghetto  generally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black man jumps up and points off right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't want no goddam abortion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A white doctor jumps in from the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's... let's get down to the core  of this matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More murmuring. A Che Guevara -- styled revolutionary mov toward Mead and Sundstrom at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is that this hospital is  the landlord for those buildings and  they should've turned them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angrily, he leans over the table facing Sundstrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those buildings are imperialistic  extensions of the medical  establishment. This hospital ought  to be rebuilding those tenements,  give those people decent housing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sundstrom raises his hands for quiet and starts to rise. hostile din has gotten to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, please, please!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, ROOM
dialogues.text: William Mead is transferred from his bed to a rolling  stretcher by an orderly in shirt and trousers and by Nurs Felicia Chile. Nurse Chile tucks Mead in. He opens his ey to look at her drowsily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under sedation) You know, I hallucinated last night.  I hallucinated there was an Indian  doing a war dance in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affably) You weren't hallucinating, Mr. Mead.  There was an Indian in here last  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring through his  sedation at her) There was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wheel him out into...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, SURGICAL AREA CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Mead is wheeled down the corridor by the orderly. At the end, an anesthetized patient, blue in the harsh light, fr from surgery, is being wheeled into a recovery room. Surgery is busy and efficient but not as clinically tidy we'd like. Linens and equipment and surgical gear are pil into corners or on empty stretchers. Green-uniformed nurs doctors and orderlies go in and out of the many doors fla the corridor. This is the non-sterilized area, where doct and nurses confer in the corridors; three black orderlies await an assignment, sit on stretchers, chuckle, mutter.  Phones can be heard RINGING. The orderly wheeling Mead tu left into the...

dialogues.speaker: SURGICAL AREA, CENTRAL PLAZA
dialogues.text: ...a small, cluttered central area with the office of the Operating Room Nursing Supervisor on the right and the Ho (for Anesthesia) Room on the left. The O.R. is like the  Emergency Ward, desperately busy but staffed by people gr so accustomed to it that they display a calm, almost casu but febrile efficiency. A large blackboard faces the  Supervisor's Office with the day's schedule of operations neatly chalked in. It is full. A middle-aged surgeon, sti in his overcoat, is studying the schedule. A green-uniformed NURSE swings through the glass doors fr the Operating Room area to lean into the Supervisor's Off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Norris says about half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Shirley it was just an ovarian  cyst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THIRD NURSE leans back into the Supervisor's Office t relay this information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shirley, it was just an ovarian cyst!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is apparently good news, for we hear someone saying

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Oh, thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An orderly rumbles by with an E.K.G. machine. O.R. Nursin Supervisor DOROTHY KIMBALL, a pleasant lady in her late  thirties, leans out of her office to speak to one of the  lounging orderlies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing the orderly  a slip) All right, Jerry, go up to Holly  Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly detaches himself from his cronies and exits. is into this atmosphere of subdued febrility that William Mead is wheeled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Kimball) William Mead from Holly Eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold him there, Tom. We've got  somebody coming out right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, a stretcher is being wheeled out of the Holding R The patient is sedated and covered. As the orderly wheels her past CAMERA, we may recognize the pale, sleeping prof of Miss Campanella, the nurse who had been coshed with a  sandbag not many scenes ago. A CIRCULATING NURSE comes th the glass doors, examines the chart dangling from the  stretcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to this nurse) Who's that? Mangafranni?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking wristband) Yeah. (to orderly) Number three, Marty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orderly wheels the silent Miss Campanella off to Oper Room Three, as Dr. Welbeck, in his natty blue suit, carry his camel coat, turns in from the outer corridor and exam the blackboard. He goes back to...

dialogues.speaker: OUTER CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...Welbeck crosses, opens a door and enters...

dialogues.speaker: SURGEONS' LOCKER ROOM
dialogues.text: All four walls are lined with lockers. Shelves and carton of green surgical clothes, caps, masks, trousers, shoe- coverings. Obviously, surgeons dress for their operations here. Two surgeons, one middle-aged and the other a young RESIDENT, are changing. The resident turns to Welbeck on entrance and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's legal for a doctor to incorporate  in New York, isn't it, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (en route to phone) Since last September. If they had  that when I was your age, I'd have  put away a couple of million by now. (dials) It gives you a variety of deferral  devices, profit-sharing for example.  Let's say you pick yourself an October  31-fiscal. You declare a bonus payable  in '71. An accrued item payable to a  principle share-holder must be paid  within two and half months after the  close of the year to get the deduction  in the prior year. But your  corporation doesn't pay that tax,  because we've eliminated the taxable  income with the bonus. With two  taxable entities, you can bury a  hell of a lot of expenses... (on phone) Hello, this is Welbeck, any  messages?... Well, I'm at the  hospital. I have to cut open some  guy in a couple of minutes. I'll try  to make it as fast as I can. How  urgent did he say it was?... Well,  Dr. Hogan made those arrangements  with the underwriters. The  Registration Statement was filed  with the S.E.C. well over a year  ago... If he calls again, have me  paged here. (hangs up, turns back  to the attentive  young doctors to  conduct his class in  medical finance while  changing into surgical  scrub) The really big money is in health  leasing, of course. Dr. Hogan, the  eminent orthopedic surgeon, and I  incorporated a leasing company and  went public last year. I hold a  controlling interest in a number of  proprietary hospitals, nursing homes  and rest farms, and I've been leasing  hospital equipment to my own hospitals  at excessive rates. Why, you ask, am  I draining my own hospitals? Well,  my hospitals are taxed at 48 percent,  and I'm giving my leasing company a  hell of a price-earnings ratio,  which'll balloon the market value of  the stock. I hold three hundred  thousand shares of that stock,  lettered of course, but in a year,  I'll dump those shares at a capital  gain and walk off with a bundle...

dialogues.speaker: OPERATING ROOM THREE
dialogues.text: Just like on TV -- well, almost. The surgeon, DR. MALLORY bad-tempered man in his fifties, sits on a stool with his gloved hands wrapped in a towel, waiting for the two surg RESIDENTS to finish painting the operable area, which hap to be the abdomen. It's a hysterectomy. The patient is sh except for the small square of abdominal area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mangafranni, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbles to one of  the residents) What do you say, huh? We're not going  to hang it in the Louvre, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The anesthesiologist, DR. CHU, injects pentathol in the I tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring a mask over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RESIDENT ANESTHESIOLOGIST trundles over the oxygen ta takes the hypodermic syringe from Dr. Chu, who now applie the oxygen mask to the enmarbled profile of the patient. studies the gauges and equipment around him at the head o the operating table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no pulse, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the pressure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no blood pressure, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pulse. Get the tube and E.K.G.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't feel a thing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room galvanizes into the swift, silent activity of a  chest massage. Dr. Mallory, standing and stretching in th back of the room, turns and moves toward the off-screen  patient. He begins a vigorous rhythmic massage of the  patient's rib cage over the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mallory thumps the patient's chest hard with his fist and the others, likewise, go to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. She must have thrown  an embolus. She was doing fine up to  now. (to Resident  Anesthesiologist) Did you check the gasses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only time I ever saw anybody  conk out like this, some jerk switched  the nitrous oxide and the gas lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scrub nurse is applying electrode paste to the  defibrillators. Dr. Mallory yanks the sheets and hospital shirt off the patient and begins very rigorous massage of the exposed ribs; we can hear one rib crack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the damn leads on. For Chrissakes,  what the hell is this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just a young woman, sir. Do  you think we should open the chest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defibrillating) She's fifty-three, you buttonhead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Bicarb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Chu, who has been inserting some suprel and bicarbona into the tube of the patient's I.V., is frowning at her r white-capped face. He leans over to check the E.K.G. read

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fibrillating, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mallory straddles the patient. He's doing heavy heart mas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus H. Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, stop for a minute... Doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Chu pushes back, the operating cap on the patient's h revealing jet-black hair. Mallory starts to massage again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barking at the scrub  nurse) You got those paddles ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Chu stares blankly at the patient's face, then looks at the sweating surgeon, perched on the operating table,  rhythmically crushing away at the patient's rib cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I may be crazy, Doctor, but I don't  think this is your patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mallory, now pausing for a moment, looks up. He is be with sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He massages away. Another rib cracks.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, BOCK'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The Supervisor of Nurses, Mrs. Christie, is sitting on a  chair reading a report. Bock, now in his doctor's coat, i hunched over his desk, hands clasped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I don't want to get into an  institutional hassle with you, Mrs.  Christie. The malpractice here is  monumental. As you see, Dr. Schaefer's  blood sugar was twenty-three. No  glucose solution is going to do that.  The only thing that will do that is  at least fifty units of insulin,  probably more. The only presumption  is that one of those nurses on the  Eighth Floor shot fifty units of  insulin into Schaefer's blood stream,  either by injection or through the  I.V., although how in God's name...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Christie's electric pocket-pager BEEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, Doctor. (reaches for a phone) May I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss McGuire leans in from the secretaries' office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bock) Doctor, did you ask the head nurse  on the eighth floor to let you know  when a Miss Drummond got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she just got there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Oh, dear me, Dorothy. I better get  right down there directly. Have you  called the O.O.D.? And you better  call Dr. Gilley. And you better call  Mr. Sloan... Yes, I'll be down  directly. (hangs up; to Bock) I'm very sorry, Doctor, but there's  a real nasty one in the O.R. They've  just operated on the wrong patient...

dialogues.speaker: O.R. NURSING SUPERVISOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Crowded now. The administrative resident, Hitchcock, is h and a uniformed man in his fifties, MR. SLOAN, the Chief Safety and Traffic. Sloan represents the Hospital's secur force. Mrs. Kimball is at her desk, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) ...well, I don't understand, is she  back in her room? When did she get  back to her room? Who brought her  back?... (she stares at  Hitchcock) She's back in her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mangafranni, the woman who was  supposed to have been operated on... (calls to a nurse  passing) Are they still working on that woman  in Three?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back on phone) I'm sorry, Mrs. Fried, would you say  that again?... Well, nobody in this  office sent her back up... Well, all  right, Mrs. Fried, I'll have to call  you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up, stands, goes out into...

dialogues.speaker: THE OPERATING AREA, PLAZA
dialogues.text: ...where three orderlies lounge about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did any of you take a woman named  Mangafranni out of the Holding Room  back up to Holly Five around ten  o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently, none of these three. Mrs. Christie turns in f the outer corridor. Normal Operating Room activity flows patients wheeled to and from their various surgeries, sur checking the blackboard, staff doctors, orderlies keeping the noise level low but steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hitchcock in the  doorway) What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock shrugs helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Christie) I don't know what happened. A patient  named Mangafranni was scheduled for  a hysterectomy at ten o'clock -- Dr.  Mallory. I talked to Sylvia in the  Holding Room who admitted her, so  she was here. And now I just spoke  to Mrs. Fried on Holly Five, and she  says an orderly brought Mrs.  Mangafranni back to her room about  twenty minutes ago. Now Mrs.  Mangafranni is in her room sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, who's the woman in the operating  room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kimball, Mrs. Christie, Hitchcock and Sloan push thr the glass doors to the crossroads of the operating rooms. Through each window, we see operating crews hacking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they had to open her up, and  that's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gather in anticipation outside O.R. Three and peer o each other's shoulders into the room where the operating  crew is hunched over the open-heart massage. The masked  circulating nurse looks up, notices the audience at the d and gives a hopeless shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better get Mr. Mead.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, THE STAFF ROOM
dialogues.text: Milton Mead is sitting in a back seat of the Staff Room - lounge with couches, easy chairs and magazine racks -- gi half an ear to the several opinions being simultaneously  expressed by:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...abortion? The clinic should be  under the supervision and entirely  staffed by women and administered by  a member of the Women's Committee  for Medical Liberation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...let's get to the core of the matter  which is the criminal and gangster  collusion between the American medical  establishment and the drug, insurance  and tobacco companies who, through  their combined racketeering efforts,  have produced a dual system of health  care. Everything for the rich and  nothing for the poor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...abortion clinic! That's genocide,  baby! You're just killing off blacks!  We consider proliferation elemental  to the class struggle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and by

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (who has lost his  cool altogether and  is screaming right  along with everyone  else) ...for God's sake! We've got eleven  people in these buildings, and we've  got to get them out of there! We can  rectify the injustices of the world  tomorrow, but right now, for God's  sake, can we get those people out of  those buildings? Will you people  please listen to me? Will you people  please shut up and listen to me?  Will you people please call a halt  to this participatory democracy and  address ourselves to the immediate  problem?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this maelstrom, the phone at Mead's elbow RINGS. M answers it, listens, nods, returns the receiver, stand an slips out of the room into the delicious silence of the..

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EXECUTIVE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...where Hitchcock emerges from the Administration office The two men move down the hall toward each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long ago did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you called the Medical Examiner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'd better do that now. And  you better call the precinct station  house as well.

dialogues.speaker: OPERATING ROOM THREE
dialogues.text: Dr. Mallory is wrenching off his blood-drenched rubber gl and flinging them to the floor in a rage. The door to the room opens, and Mrs. Kimball, Mrs. Christie and Mr. Sloan enter. Dr. Mallory is stupefied with anger. Dr. Chu, bles with Eastern containment, blandly gathers his equipment  together, nods to Mrs. Christie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is really something, isn't it?  I thought she looked a little  different when they brought her in.  I even said to one of the nurses,  "She looks a little younger without  her dentures." I'd only talked to  her half an hour before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anybody know who she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mallory can only stare at her numbly. He turns and st numbly at Mr. Sloan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Kimball,  examining the chart  dangling from the  operating table) What's her chart say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her chart says Mangafranni. Her  bracelet says Mangafranni. The only  thing that isn't Mangafranni is the  woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Mallory finally explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus H. Christ! I've been chopping  out three uteruses a day for twenty  years, and is it too much to expect  for you people to bring in the right  goddam Jesus Christ uterus?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had just been talking to her in  the Holding Room. She was perfectly  fine. A little drowsy. I thought it  was funny that when they brought her  in, she was out cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuffling around in  aimless circles) Jesus H. Kee-rist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Christie stares down at the face of the dead patient the table, who has had her chest spread wide open so that the organs are exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we'll just all have to stay  here until Mr. Mead or someone from  the O.O.D. comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not taking the rap for  this! I've already got one malpractice  suit pending, and I'm not taking the  rap for this one!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, ROOM
dialogues.text: William Mead's bed is empty. The Reverend Drummond's suit still on its hanger, is lying on it. Drummond himself lie comatose and rigged out with I.V.s and catheters. Barbara Drummond is packing her father's things into an open one- suiter valise. The door opens. She looks up. It's Bock. T look at each other -- two people in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you're not going. I love you,  and I'm not going to let you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the suit lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's start putting your  father's things back. He's staying  here. (hangs the suit in  the closet) I'll find an apartment somewhere.  I'm staying in a filthy little hotel  room. We can't use that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are caught by a white doctor's uniform hanging i the armoire along with the suits and overcoats of the two patients in the room. He bends over to peer at the namepl over the breast pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't make it here, Herb. I'll  crack up. I cracked up once already.  One week here, and I'd be running  naked through the streets screaming  again. I can retain my sanity only  in a simple society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Barbara, you can't  seriously see me living in a grass  shack hunting jackrabbits for dinner?  Be sensible for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am being sensible. What is it you're  so afraid of leaving here? Your  plastic home? Your conditioned air?  Your synthetic clothes? Your instant  food? I'm offering you green silence  and solitude, the natural order of  things. Mostly, I'm offering me. I  think we're beautiful, Herb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (utterly in love) You make it sound almost plausible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why you even hesitate.  What's holding you here? Is it your  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's all over. I suppose if  I'm married to anything, it's this  hospital. It's been my whole life. I  just can't walk out on it as if it  never mattered. I'm middle-class.  Among us middle-class, love doesn't  triumph over all. Responsibility  does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herb, don't ask me to stay here with  you, because I love you, and I will.  And we'll both be destroyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to her again. They both look away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the bill here to pay yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gathers her raincoat and goes. Bock follows her out i the...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EIGHTH FLOOR, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...where Dr. Joseph Lagerman, Head of Nephrology, perhaps remembered from an earlier scene, has been waiting for Bo He joins them en route to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herb, you asked me to find that  dialysis nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What dialysis nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara has continued walking. Bock starts to follow her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go pay the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one who goofed on your patient,  Drummond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock turns back to Lagerman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, her name is Theresa Campanella,  but you are not going to believe  this, Herb. She died on the operating  table in O. R. Three about an hour  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is disappearing into an elevator. Bock starts aft her, then turns back to Lagerman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, she died on the  operating table in O.R. Three?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurry down the corridor to the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean she was the one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one. I just identified  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on around here?  Every time I try to find somebody in  this hospital, they either died of a  heart attack in Emergency or of  anesthesia shock in an operating  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elevator doors open. A nurse and visitor get out. Bock an Lagerman go into...

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Two or three people besides the elevator operator are the as well as a patient on a stretcher and an orderly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I just came from the O.R.  They're trying to find a Dr. Schaefer.  Don't you have a kid named Schaefer  in your service?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowls, mutters) I had a Schaefer. He died yesterday  of an overdose of insulin. What do  they want Schaefer for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Holding Room nurse says there  was a Dr. Schaefer hanging around  the Holding Room. It wouldn't have  been your Schaefer anyway. The nurse  says it was senior staff, a middle- aged man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no senior staff named Schaefer  in this hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told them that. I said, I don't  know any senior staff around here  named Schaefer. They've got detectives  down there, everything. It's a whole  big investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator stops at the seventh floor. The doors open a Bock and Lagerman stroll into...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, SEVENTH FLOOR, CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Bock lumbers down the west corridor, turns into...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: William Mead, sedated and apparently zonked out cold, is  being transferred from a stretcher back into bed by an O. orderly and nurse's aid. Bock rolls back the curtains aro Drummond's bed revealing the comatose patient, his face  sculptured against the white pillow, an I.V. tube in his  right arm, a catheter projecting from under the sheet. Bo lowers the protective railing, leans in, takes the man's  pulse on his neck, raises one closed eyelid, then the oth The pupils stare vacuously back at him; the eyelids drop  closed as soon as they are released. In the background, the orderly and aid finish tucking in  William Mead and exit, wheeling their creaking stretcher  out. The room is shockingly silent. Bock goes to the wind and frowns in thought. HOLD ACROSS the patient Drummond, on Bock in the backgrou at the window with his back to us. Suddenly, Drummond's e open. He lies rigid, his eyes staring dementedly into the air above him. Slowly, his left hand reaches out and carefully withdraws the catheter from his bladder, lays it on the white sheet beside him, and silently reaches over to withdraw the I.V needle from his right arm. He lets the needle dangle, dri onto the bed. Carefully, he twists out from under his she swings his legs over the side of the bed and sits up. REVERSE ACROSS Bock at the window, pondering. With a swif lash of movement, the double tubes of a stethoscope are  whipped over his head and tightened around his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mad as a hatter) I am the Fool for Christ and the  Paraclete of Caborca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE TWO SHOT of Bock being strangled, Drummond's face f in bland dementia behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) For heaven's sake, Dad! What the  hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummond pauses in his strangling and, releasing the poor man altogether, turns to his daughter in the doorway. CAMERA DOLLIES to include all three -- Bock recuperating; Drummond staring madly; and Barbara infuriated with her  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed) We all thought you were at Death's  Door! What're you doing out of bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummond, abashed, stands there, a scolded schoolboy, a  rawboned figure in a hospital shift, a stethoscope dangli from his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bock) What happened? Did he say anything  to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sufficiently recovered) As a matter of fact, he said, "I am  the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete  of Caborca." And you'd better close  the door, because if he's going to  tell everyone who walks in here he's  the Fool for Christ and the Paraclete  of Caborca, they'll put us all away.  He's already killed two doctors and  one nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the wrath of the lamb and the  angel of the bottomless pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean he killed two doctors  and a nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, he's killed two doctors and  a nurse! And he just tried to kill  me! He has something against doctors.  Somehow he got hold of a thousand  units of insulin and put it in Dr.  Schaefer's intravenous solution. And  somehow he got Dr. Ives to die of a  heart attack in the middle of the  Emergency Room. And somehow he got a  dialysis nurse named Campanella to  die of anesthesia shock on an  operating table! (opens the closet,  points to the white  doctor's uniform  hanging there) He's been running around the hospital  wearing Dr. Schaefer's uniform. Right  now, they're looking all over the  place for this mysterious Dr.  Schaefer. I know this all sounds as  grotesque to you as it does to me,  but you can see for yourself your  father is not the helpless comatose  patient we thought he was. Don't  look at me like I'm the one who's  crazy. Ask your crazy father!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was merely an instrument of God. I  killed no one. They all three died  by their own hands, ritual victims  of their own institutions, murdered  by irony, an eye for an eye, biblical  retribution. Schaefer was first, you  see, because he killed God. God was  admitted to this hospital last Monday  under the name of Guernsey...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806. MORNING., (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: A cheerless, gray sunlight fills the room as the fragile, white-haired and bearded old Guernsey (whose admittance t the hospital was the opening scene of the film) is being  helped into the room by Nurse Felicia Chile. She solicito helps the wispy old man off with his coat and jacket and which she puts in the armoire. With palsied fingers, the  little old man unknots his stringy tie and unbuttons the  collar, which is three sizes too large. In the other bed, Drummond's eyes slowly open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) I was instantly aware of a divine  presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man is slipping out of his clothes to expose a th little body in a torn nightshirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) I was convinced this porcelain old  man was, in fact, an Angel of the  Lord...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man sits back, wheezing a little. Nurse Chile smi nicely at him and takes her leave. For a moment, Drummond lies rigidly on his bed, staring dully into the air and t old man sits with his hunched back to us. The room is sil except for his rheumy wheeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) ...perhaps even Christ Himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, the old man rises and goes to the washbas and, with some wheezing, spits into it. He shuffles back bed. Dr. Schaefer comes into the room with a professional smile and the patient Guernsey's chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Our Savior was, it seems, suffering  from emphysema.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schaefer perches on the bed beside Guernsey and begins to take his history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) He was relentlessly subjected to the  benefits of modern medicine. He was  misdiagnosed, mismedicated, and put  into shock by Dr. Schaefer; raced  off to Intensive Care, where the  resident compounded the blunder and  induced a coma. I can tell you with  authority that God is indeed dead.  He died last Monday under the name  of Guernsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of Drummond in deep shadow shows him sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) A few hours later, he appeared to me  in a revelation.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806. NIGHT, 7
dialogues.text: The room is lit only by the yellow light from the half-op bathroom door. Guernsey walks out of the shadows, hands  raised. He shuffles to Drummond's bedside and looks down him from his frail height.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Rise up, Drummond. You are dead, now  you are restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummond's eyes open and roll to the direction of the voi DRUMMOND'S P.O.V.: Guernsey, dressed only in his hospital shift, is shuffling up and down the aisle of the room, ha clasped behind his back like a Mittel-European intellectu head hunched forward -- a little old man with a white bea talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those who killed you and those who  killed me will die in our place. You  are the Paraclete of Caborca, the  wrath of the lamb. The angel of the  bottomless pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guernsey closes his eyes in religious ecstacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In this fashion has it been revealed  to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummond starts to sob and slowly sits up in his bed, imb with belief. He looks mutely up at the frail old man, who now raises his right hand and his face is transfigured in vast majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thunders out) The age is closed! The end is at  hand! The seal is broken!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So saying, he reverts to the little old man he was, wheez a bit, and with some effort, climbs back on his bed and l there, eyes closed. His thin, high nose projects from the whiteness of his face. He sighs the rattling last sigh of life and dies. CAMERA DOLLIES slowly to CLOSE-UP of Drumm lying motionless on his bed. His eyes are wide, glinting the shadows, a man imbued. His cheeks are wet with tears exaltation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Well! Not quite the burning bush  perhaps but prodigal enough for me.  I was to avenge the death of God and  my own brutalization. I was to kill  Doctors Schaefer, Ives and Welbeck  and the dialysis nurse Miss  Campanella, whose negligence caused  my coma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT of Drummond. He raises his left hand, flexing h fingers. Then he moves his other arm, his head, his shoul Obviously, he is regaining his faculties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) I awaited a further sign from God,  which was given to me later that  evening. Dr. Schaefer, it seems, had  arranged an assignation with a girl  from the hematology lab named Sheila.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACROSS Drummond to the now empty other bed. All the light are on. PAN on Nurse Penny Canduso and an orderly wheelin away the wrapped body of Guernsey. Intern Schaefer, at th door, considers the empty bed with interest. Moving to th bedtable, he picks up the receiver of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hey Sheila, this is Howard, Sheila.  Hey listen, I got us a bed for  tonight. A real, honest-to-god bed.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806. NIGHT
dialogues.text: REPRISE the scene originally played UNDER CREDITS where D Schaefer and his girlfriend Sheila sneak into the room an undress. Giggles and shushings, gooses and fondles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I sure hope nobody walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the replay, however, an additional segment is adde At one point, the girl, hanging her dress in the armoire, turns and holds something up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this in your pocket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my insulin. Put it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you take insulin for?  Diabetes? I didn't know you were a  diabetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't contagious, don't worry  about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head for the unoccupied bed. CLOSE-UP on Drummond's  profile.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: Dark, hushed. Schaefer's girl is leaving; she tiptoes to door, peeks out. Apparently, the coast is clear. She quic slips out.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806. DAY
dialogues.text: Drummond on his chair. Barbara perched on one side of her father's bed, Bock on the other. William Mead sleeps on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you put Schaefer's insulin into  the I.V. jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And then a second nurse came  and plugged the I.V. jar into  Schaefer. God clearly intended a  measure of irony here. The hospital  was to do all the killing for me.  All I need do was arrange for the  doctors to become patients in their  own hospital. Accordingly, the next  morning, I set out for Dr. Ives. I  put on Dr. Schaefer's uniform, pinched  some digoxine from the pharmacy and  a sandbag from a utility cart, and  found my way to Dr. Ives' laboratory.  I coshed him with the sandbag, gave  him a massive shot of the digoxine.  This, you see, brought on an instant  condition of cardiac arrhythmia.  When he came to, I brought him down  to the Emergency Room.

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY ROOM AREA, LOBBY. DAY
dialogues.text: The usual E.R. crush and motion goes on in the background Drummond escorts an obviously ill Dr. Ives to the Admitti Room. Drummond's voice under the narration explains matte to Miss Aronovici at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Ives. He's in the  Nephrology Lab. I was in there a  little while ago, and he was suddenly  taken ill, and I thought I'd better  get him over here right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) He had at that time perhaps an hour  to live. Prompt treatment would have  saved his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go into the...

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY ADMITTING AND TREATMENT ROOMS
dialogues.text: Ives, seated on a table in evident distress, breathes hea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice-off) As a staff doctor, he was seen without  preliminaries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attendant takes his pulse, pressure and respiration. I collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice-off) His vital signs were taken, an  electrocardiogram...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN SLOWLY across the Emergency Room to catch its state o contained febrility. Every curtained treatment room is  occupied, including the storage room in the back. The tri nurse and a second nurse behind the desk are busy on the  phones. The triage nurse takes the history of the first i line of five people seeking admission even as she answers her phone. We watch Miss Aronovici and the other nurse and Dr. Spezi and his two interns, the two attendants -- all busy with patient or another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice-off) ...which revealed occasional  ventricular premature contractions.  An intern took his history...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ACROSS Drummond, white-uniformed, standing in the back ag the filing cabinets and linens, watching the the new pati trickle and crowd in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice-off) ...and then he was promptly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Admitting Desk, a MAN in his forties is being sign in by a uniformed cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice-off) ...simply... forgotten to death.  Simply mislaid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA JUST STARES at the pageant of pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice-off) ...mislaid among the broken wrists,  the chest pains, scalp lacerations,  the man whose fingers were crushed  in a taxi door, the infant with the  skin rash, the child swiped by a  car, the old lady mugged in the  subway, the derelict beaten by  sailors, the teenage suicide, the  paranoids, drunks, asthmatics, the  rapes, the septic abortions, the  overdosed addicts...

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY ROOM AREA, LOBBY
dialogues.text: Looking to the street doors as two ambulance attendants,  bearing a seventeen-year-old black girl on a stretcher, b in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Not breathing! Not breathing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurry into the Admitting Room past a nurse and into  the...

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY ADMITTING AND TREATMENT ROOMS
dialogues.text: ...which is already galvanized into action. Miss Aronovic is at the girl's pulse even as she is being transferred t the bed that has just been cleared of Mr. Mitgang and his concussion case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (instructing attendant  with Mitgang) Better put him in the Holding Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with the seventeen- year-old girl) She's taking a little pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to triage nurse) Get an anesthesiologist, one-five- one-five...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On screen we continue watching the scene of the overdose  case treatment, as the live-action sound in the room fade behind Drummond's tale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) ...the fractures, infarcts,  hemorrhages, concussions, boils,  abrasions, the colonic cancers, the  cardiac arrests -- the whole wounded  madhouse of our times...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REACTION SHOT of Drummond staring at this ceaseless panor of pain, tears streaking down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) I wonder if I could have a minute of  your time, Doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drummond turns to the voice. CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the man who had been brought into the E.R. by a uniformed cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the fool for Christ and the  Paraclete of Caborca.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's an honor and a privilege,  Doctor. I've been here ten minutes,  I can't seem to get anybody to help  me. I'm suffering from some sort of  amnesia. I can't remember my name.  As a matter of fact, it's pretty  screwy. I got mugged. Two hours ago,  walking out of a coffee shop on Fifty- Seventh Street and Second Avenue,  eight o'clock in the morning, broad  daylight, I got mugged. A sixteen- year-old girl walks up to me, shows  me a knife about a yard long and  says, "Give me your wallet." I thought  she was kidding. I mean there's  hundreds of people walking right by.  Well, she wasn't kidding. "Listen,"  I said, "all I got's about twenty  bucks." So she takes the wallet  anyway. So I said, "How about leaving  me my identification?" I mean, I had  my driver's license, my Diner's Club,  my credit cards. But she took them  all, the whole damn wallet, credit  cards, everything. So I stopped some  guy, I said, "Hey, you see that girl  there, walking away?" He says, "Yeah."  I said, "She just stole my wallet,  credit cards and everything." He  says, "Well, that's what they want,  the credit cards." So I started  looking for a cop. I mean, go find a  cop, right? Well, I finally find a  cop. The girl's halfway to South  America by now, probably bought the  ticket with my credit cards. So the  cop says, "What's your name?" And  you want to know something? I couldn't  think of my name. The girl took all  my identification, you know what I  mean? She took all my credit cards.  So I said, "You know this is screwy.  I can't think of my name." So he  took me to the station house. The  sergeant says, "What's your name?" I  said, "I don't know! She took all my  credit cards!" So they took me down  here. So what do you think, Doctor?  I'm nuts, right? I finally flipped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN SLOWLY to Drummond who stares at the Nameless Man. In BACKGROUND the door opens and Mrs. Cushing, the lady f accounting, enters. She calls out in her annoying voice f a chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's number 7-6-8-0-2-S? Is there  anybody here who is that number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
