dialogues.text: (off-screen) In this way was it revealed to me  the manner of Nurse Campanella's  death. She was to die of the great  American plague -- vestigial identity.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806. DAY
dialogues.text: Drummond in his hospital shift, gaunt and mad as a prophe sits rigidly on his chair. Barbara perches on her father' bed. Bock wanders disorientedly about the room, staring  incredulously first at Barbara and then at her father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So last night, I coshed Miss  Campanella with a sandbag, sedated  her with thorazine, shaved her,  prepped her, and parked her in a  corridor of the X-Ray Department for  five hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why X-Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at X-Ray, a sedated body lying  around unattended for five hours  wouldn't seem unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her operation -- that is to say,  Mrs. Mangafranni's operation -- was  not scheduled until nine-thirty. So  at nine-fifteen this morning, I rang  for my nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You rang for your nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To insure one full hour of  uninterrupted privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got up, wheeled Miss Campanella  off to the operating rooms, replaced  her bed with Mrs. Mangafranni's,  exchanged charts and identity  bracelets. She died officially of  anesthesia shock. But, in point of  fact, she died because she was wearing  another woman's identity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bock) God, what do we do now? Let me take  him back to Mexico. It's a simple  world there. If you turn him in,  they'll just cage him in the Rockland  State Hospital for the Criminally  Insane. Let me take him back, Herb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? We'll both take  him. I'm going with you! Get him  dressed. We're getting out of here  before the police put us all in  Rockland State.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't finished my work here. I  have this Welbeck to dispose of. I  am the angel of the bottomless pit  and the wrath of the lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, he's having another  revelation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock holds Drummond's coat and hat and crosses to take hi arm. He finds the entranced Drummond as rigid as a statue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, that ambulance must be here by  now. You go down and get them. I'll  give him a shot of something to knock  him out. We'll take him to the airport  in the ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both hurry out of the room. Drummond remains enmarbl in his trance. CAMERA SUDDENLY MOVES DOWN to William Mead whose eyes now open; he has heard it all. In background,  Drummond, suddenly released from his catatonic trance, he for the armoire and extracts the white trousers of Dr.  Schaefer's uniform. He puts them on, tucking in the tails his hospital shift. He notices William Mead staring at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hallucinating again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Mead just stares at Drummond.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, NURSES' STATION AND LOBBY AREA
dialogues.text: Bock and Barbara come hurrying around the corner from the west corridor. Barbara heads for the elevators. Bock head for the Nurses' Station. The Eighth Floor is going about normal 1:15 P.M. activity. Mrs. Donovan is at her desk on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Edwards never showed up. I'm short- staffed as hell. It's just me and  Felicia. It's like Sunday. Nobody's  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be at lunch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nurse's aid, a bathrobed patient and two of his visitor stroll by. It's the end of the lunch hour, when the kitch workers bring used trays back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you gotta send me somebody...  Oh yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock moves past Mrs. Donovan and into the pharmacy where see him scouring the shelves for thorazine and a syringe. elevator arrives, disgorging Milton Mead and his resident assistant, Thomas Hitchcock and, of all people, Dr. Richa Welbeck himself. Barbara and Dr. Biegelman go into the  elevator. The doors close. Milton Mead and Hitchcock head for the west corridor. Welbeck, in his natty double-breas suit and carrying his cashmere coat, heads straight for t Nurses' Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be in Eight-O-Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckles into phone) ...then what did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mrs. Donovan) I'm Dr. Welbeck. I have a patient on  this floor named Drummond, and I'd  like to see his chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock immediately emerges from the pharmacy holding a bott of thorazine and a wrapped hypodermic syringe. He scowls Welbeck, who scowls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Dr. Bock. Can I have a few minutes  of your time, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to pass Mrs. Donovan and would continue, but We lays a restraining hand on his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gilley tells me you're the one  who initiated these proceedings  against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy, Welbeck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to know what you have against  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned up half-stoned for a simple  nephrectomy eight days ago, botched  it, put the patient into failure and  damn near killed him. Then, pausing  only to send in your bill, you flew  off on the wings of man to an island  of sun in Montego Bay. This is the  third time in two years we've had to  patch up your patients; the other  two died. You're greedy, unfeeling,  inept, indifferent, self-inflating  and unconscionably profitable. Aside  from that, I have nothing against  you. I'm sure you play a hell of a  game of golf. What else do you want  to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welbeck's pocket-beeper BEEPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me for a moment, Doctor. (he reaches over the  nurses' desk for a  phone) This is Dr. Welbeck. Were you paging  me? (regarding Bock with  cold scorn) How much do you make a year, Bock?  For a guy who makes a lousy forty,  fifty grand... (on phone) Hello, Arthur, I understand you've  been trying to reach me all morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock turns and heads back for...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, WEST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...and down that through the kitchen workers and strollin patients to...

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: ...which he enters. He is startled to find Milton Mead an Hitchcock leaning over William Mead, who is up on one elb and in a state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, Milton, he pulls  out all the wires and the tubes, and  he gets up and puts on a doctor's  uniform, and he goes out, and he  murders doctors! He just went out  ten seconds before you came in!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, there is no Drummond to be seen. His bed is empty Bock nods to Milton Mead and Hitchcock, who nod back, and crosses quickly to look into the bathroom which is likewi empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll tell you something else  about this crazy place you got here!  There was a naked Indian in here  last night doing a war dance! That's  the kind of crazy place you're running  here, Milton! You got to get me out  of here, Milton. This is a crazy  place, Milton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milton Mead's pocket-beeper BEEPS. Milton Mead reaches fo the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appealing to Bock) I wake up last night, there's a goddam  Indian in here, a naked Indian! What  kind of hospital is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) This is Mr. Mead, are you paging me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of hours later I wake up  again, and the guy in that bed there  is getting out of the bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hitchcock) Are the police still in the building?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better get them up here. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All day long, he lays there like a  dead man. All of a sudden, in the  middle of the night, he gets out of  bed! I thought I was going crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Yes, this is Mead... Oh, dear.  When?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what he says to me? He says,  you're hallucinating. Listen, I just  saw a naked Indian. Now, I'm seeing  a ghost. I got to figure he's right,  I'm hallucinating, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be down directly. (hangs up) Never rains but it pours. A fire  just broke out in one of those  condemned buildings. The squatters  in the building came out. The police  tried to arrest them and, apparently,  the situation has erupted into a  riot. (to Bock as he heads  for the door) I'm sure you're wondering what this  is all about, Herb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to leave me alone  in this crazy place, Milton!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (at the door with  Bock) Mr. Hitchcock is staying with you. (to Hitchcock) You better call the cops, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milton! Milton! Milton!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door slams.

dialogues.speaker: WEST CORRIDOR AND NURSES' STATION
dialogues.text: Bock and Milton Mead stride up the corridor through the l wagons and kitchen carts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't the time now, and I'm not  even going to try to tell you this  curious story my brother just told  me. I'll fill you in on it at lunch  some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waves his hand helplessly to indicate the utter incred of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushes not to miss  the elevator) Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach an open elevator. Mead goes in, the doors clos The doors of a second elevator then open, and Barbara com out. She and Bock stare at each other. In background, Wel is on the phone at the Nurses' Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but your father isn't. He's  disappeared. He put on Schaefer's  uniform and has gone out to do God's  work, presumably the murder of Dr.  Welbeck. Except, that fellow on the  phone over there is Dr. Welbeck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in background on  phone) Oh my God, Arthur! What are you  talking about? Have you talked to  Dr. Hogan about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, on top of everything else, the  other patient in your father's room  overheard his whole confession and  just told the Chief Administrator of  the hospital. They're sending for  the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ACROSS Welbeck on phone at Nurses' Station. In th background, Bock and Barbara stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost apoplectic on  phone) Oh, my God, Arthur. Well, who held  title? Do the underwriters know about  this yet?... Oh my God! Arthur,  what're you waiting for? Arrest the  son of a bitch! Turn him in!... Oh  my God! When?... Of course, Arthur,  call me right back. I'm at the Holly  Pavilion, Eighth Floor. Please! Right  away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Welbeck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right?! That son of a bitch is  trying to wipe me out! My partner,  the eminent orthopedic surgeon, Dr.  Noel Hogan, is a miserable thief.  And he's trying to wipe me out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending a chart) Mr. Drummond's chart, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily seizes the  chart) What room is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight-O-Six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm expecting a phone call. Put it  straight through to me in that room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides off angrily, followed by an anxious Bock and  Barbara, for the...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, WEST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Bock and Barbara hurry along in Welbeck's wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The son of a bitch has been draining  the company with phony purchase orders  on another company, of which, it now  turns out, his wife is the principal  stockholder! Transparent fraud! I'll  send him up for twenty years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wrenches open the door of 806, marches in, followed by Bock and Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, ROOM
dialogues.text: Welbeck advances on William Mead's bed, since he is the o patient in the room. (Hitchcock is on the phone.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Drummond, you don't seem that  much the worse for the wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Mead stares dully at Welbeck. Then he looks dully Bock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hitchcock) Would you mind using some other phone?  I'm expecting an important call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? Who... who is this  guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Yes, well, I'll be at the Nurses'  Desk, Sergeant. It would be futile  for me to try to explain this to you  over the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leafing through  Drummond's chart) You've got a bit of fever, Drummond,  but you're coming along very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not Drummond, you monkey!  Drummond's the other bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone now BUZZES. Welbeck and Hitchcock both head for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's mine. (on phone) It's Welbeck here... Yes, Arthur, go  ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Mead is painfully trying to get off his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting out of this nuthouse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pushing him gently  back) All right, take it easy, Mr. Mead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock, satisfied the call is not for him, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came in here just to get a lousy  polyp cut out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Oh, my God, what do you mean? How  many transactions were there? Bu...  but Arthur, I... I borrowed against  that stock! I'm in the hole for over  three hundred thousand!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appealing to the  gods) I'm a sick man! I'm supposed to have  peace and quiet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone and  apoplectic) What do you mean, Brazil?! I just  spoke to Hogan's office yesterday,  and they just told me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone slips from his fingers. He turns to stare at Bo and Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wiped out. The S.E.C. has  suspended trading in my stock!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keels over like a felled tree, falling face-up on  Drummond's bed, his legs dangling to the floor. William M promptly hides his head under his sheet. Bock moves quickly to the prostrate Welbeck, feels his th for the carotid pulse, pulls out his stethoscope, rips  Welbeck's shirt open, and listens for heartsounds. He pic up the dangling telephone receiver, gets a dial tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Cardiac arrest, Holly Eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara strips off her coat. She is still in nurse's unif She leans into the hall and calls a passing nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an emergency here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rips off Welbeck's  natty jacket) Breathe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara helps Bock get Welbeck's dead weight onto the flo On his knees, Bock straddles Welbeck's prone form, balls fist and belts Welbeck on his chest. He begins intensive  heart massage. Barbara gets down on her knees, opens Welb mouth and commences mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. In the  background, the P.A. system blandly echoes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) C.A.C. Holly Eight. Please clear all  corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Donovan and aides move C.A.C. into the room, immedia followed by Intern Chandler rushing past them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Biegelman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went to lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Natch. Get that other bed out of  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William Mead, of course, is still huddled under his sheet He peers out from under his covers in wide-eyed disbelief and ducks under again. Bock massages Welbeck's heart. Bar continues mouth-to-mouth. Nurse Felicia Chile hurries in, pushing the emergency cart before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Nurse Chile as  others begin moving  William Mead's bed  out of the room) Give him an ambu bag and an airway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) What's been happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Chile has shunted the emergency cart aside to let t bed out and is extracting an ambu bag and tube from the c lower shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Seventh Floor  Nursing Supervisor  just outside door) Watch it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) C.A.C. Holly Eight. Please clear all  corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Chile hands the Berman airway and ambu bag to Barba who inserts the airway and the ambu tube into Welbeck's m and pumps in air by hand. Bock massages away.

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, WEST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Mrs. Donovan and Intern Chandler finally get Mead and his bed out into the corridor where they park it. In backgrou emergency activity on all sides. The resident cardiologis DR. GEOFFREY MORSE, and anesthesiologist, DR. LAWRENCE LO both thirty-three, come hurtling around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows Morse in as, from the lobby corner, two  technicians come racing a max cart and an I.V. stand befo them. Behind them, a bewildered Hitchcock moves into view trying to determine what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Intern Chandler) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Dr. Robert Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the patients had a cardiac  arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock looks down at the sheeted figure hunched on the bed parked in the hallway and slowly pulls the sheet off head. William Mead stares up at him like a hunted animal. Hitchcock covers Mead's head again.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: Bock still massages, sweating bullets by now. Barbara wor the ambu bag. Dr. Morse is feeling Welbeck's groin for hi femoral pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have, Dr. Bock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total cardiac arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Dr. Rigby. Dr. Rigby. Dr. Lilac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has he been like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About a minute. No pulse, no  heartbeat, no respiration...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we can see anything of Welbeck through other bodies, w notice almost all his clothes have been ripped off his bo Dr. Loomis replaces Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll take over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two nursing supervisors have been getting the max car ready, snapping up the gateleg-footrest and attaching the I.V. tube to the oxygen jar, and that to the ambu bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endotrachial tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rushing in background  with others) I'm sorry, Doctor, but we have another  emergency in 823.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endotrachial tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we get him up on the cart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drs. Loomis, Bock and Morse struggle to lift the the near naked dead weight of Dr. Welbeck up from the floor and on the max cart. Dr. Morse has picked up Drummond's chart fr the bed where Welbeck had left it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, who is this patient? What's  the story on this patient?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP of Bock trying to hoist Welbeck and looking up  slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this his chart, Dr. Bock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock cocks his head to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's his name? Drummond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock looks across to Barbara, now helping out at the max  cart. She looks back at Bock. She shrugs. He shrugs. They exchange a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, his name's Drummond. That's his  chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straining under the effort, the three doctors get Welbeck off the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying the chart) Oh Christ, the poor son of a bitch  just had a nephrectomy a week ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Donovan exits into...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, WEST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...as Mrs. Donovan comes out, Hitchcock turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it Drummond?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else would it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitchcock silently thanks God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Pick him up. Put him on it. Stop the  massage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welbeck's body is finally on the max cart. Nurses and doc converge on him. Dr. Loomis sets about intubating Welbeck and the Nursing Supervisor begins clamping the metal band of the E.K.G. machine on each of Welbeck's extremities. While all this goes on, Bock and Barbara have picked up t remnants of Welbeck's jacket, trousers, shirt and underwe Dr. Morse is squatting by the max-cart reading the E.K.G. script as it rolls slowly out of the cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ventricular fibrillation. Get me the  paddles. Push another amp of bicarb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nursing Supervisor starts applying electrode paste to the defibrillating paddles. Another nurse measures off an ampule of bicarbonate of soda which Dr. Loomis injects in the I.V. tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set it for two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara unsnaps her father's valise and stuffs Welbeck's  garments in it. Bock takes Welbeck's coat and piles Drumm things on top of that. The Nursing Supervisor hands Dr. Morse the defibrillating paddles to place on Welbeck's left breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) That's two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody bock away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All back away from the max-cart. Bock and Barbara are at window, piled up with valise and coats; they look like th off for Europe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) One-two-three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes the defibrillating button, sending an electric  shock through Welbeck's body so as to bounce it into the  air. Bock and Barbara remain at the window with heart-resuscit team in background. Barbara slips into her own coat, in  preparation for escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in background) Did he convert?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in background) No, he's still fibrillating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in background) Let's go to four hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce to Bock) What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock is staring out the window. Barbara stares out with h THEIR P.O.V.: looking down onto the U-shaped drive of the entrance plaza of the hospital and First Avenue full of  traffic. A band of some fifty black and Puerto Rican yout including females and young white revolutionaries, most i Che Guevara garb, have broken past the security guards at the gates and spill across the drive. Some policemen and  security guards move tentatively out of the hospital to  intercept them. The shouting can't be heard from up here. Off-screen we h the activities of the resuscitation team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) It's four hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Everybody back One-two-three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND of the shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) That didn't work either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Low crowd noises. Bock looks out the window at the protes mob below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) All right. Let me have a c.c. of  Adrenaline and intercardiac needle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PANS SLOWLY UP over the melee in the plaza to the  fence. Barbara and Bock stare down at the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off-screen) Stop the massage. Ventricular  fibrillation. Put another amp of  bicarb. Two hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZOOM DOWN into the maelstrom to FULL SHOT of the Reverend Drummond dressed in Schaefer's white uniform, standing on the slim island separating the uptown traffic from the  downtown traffic. Drummond is a private island of his own hands stretched to the skies. He is prophesying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible above  the traffic rumbling  heedlessly around  him) Let those who are in Judea flee to  the mountains, for the age is closed,  the season of the seventh seal is at  hand!

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 806
dialogues.text: Bock and Barbara slip through doctors and nurses, heading for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang isopril, two in five hundred.  Let's take one more crack with the  paddles. Everybody back off the cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock, carrying two overcoats, and Barbara, wearing hers a carrying her father's valise, exit into...

dialogues.speaker: EIGHTH FLOOR, WEST CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: ...as Bock and Barbara come out, the activity is normal,  with the exception of William Mead's bed along the wall.  Hitchcock and two overcoated men are in the hallway, and  Hitchcock hurries to Bock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can't get him out of fib. I  don't think he'll make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God. (sighs, turns to the  two detectives) This should close the case, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock and Barbara hurry toward the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: THE HOSPITAL, HOLLY PAVILION, LOBBY
dialogues.text: The small army of militants and activists has broken thro the security into the lobby. Their entrance is greeted by one small scream from a woman in the lobby. A LEADER of t invading troop calls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody take it easy! Nobody's  going to be hurt! We just want the  Director!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Others in the troop shout reassurances, but it doesn't re reassure anybody. The lady in the gift shop closes her do and locks up. People crowd in a solid block in the doorwa to the coffee shop to see what's going on. From the long tunnels of corridors, nurses, doctors,  administrative personnel pause in their chores and errand and missions to watch the tide of events in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, EXECUTIVE CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: The exit door is wrenched open, and Bock comes hurtling i the carpeted executive corridor toward the lobby, and at  that moment the troop of militants come rumbling in from other end. Every door of the corridor fills with secretar and administrators unsure of what's happening. Then, Sund elbows his way through the clutch of secretaries in his  doorway and comes into the corridor. He regards the milit moving down the corridor toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want Sundstrom! We want Sundstrom!  Community control! Community control!  Hip-hip-Hippocrates! Up with service!  Down with fees!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You people want to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, baby, we want to see you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're taking over this hospital,  man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had it up to here. I'm not  dealing with this kind of cheap  blackmail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, man. Now wait a minute  there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for a hostage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen people just got arrested  for doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background, one of their fellow revolutionaries sp up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookit, man, where's the TV camera?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but he's shut up by the Leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be cool, man? (now yelling) Fourteen people got arrested for  doing nothing but living in their  homes, which you people threw them  out of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now we're going to arrest you.  We're going to hold you hostage and  we ain't letting you go un...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ambler, the medical student we met during Bock's teaching rounds, pushes in front of the Leader to face Sundstrom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, the members of the Doctors  Liberation Committee indict this  hospital for the criminal neglect of  the community in which it is situated!  We demand an immediate dissolution  of the governing and executive boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do about those  fourteen ghetto people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the shouts continue, Sundstrom raises a hand to quiet crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not going to do anything...  about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By God, if you want to take over  this hospital, you take it over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will! Right on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You run it! I am finished! I quit!  You run it! You pay the bills! You  fight the city!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fight the state! You fight the  unions. You fight the community!  You... you think you can do a better  job, you do it! Now I am finished! I  quit! It's all yours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes filled with tears of rage, Sundstrom lowers his head and moves into the mass of militants, which parts for him leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quit! Quit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mass engulfs Sundstrom, moving back out into the lobb with him, pushing him, shoving him, humiliating him. REACTION SHOT of Bock watching it all from the far end of the corridor. He closes his eyes and the pain of watching all this shows on his face. He opens his eyes. The corrid is now silent and empty. He hurries to...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY PAVILION, THE LOBBY
dialogues.text: Bock rushes in, as the milling throng dissolves into the  bystanders, security police and city cops. Common sense h settled in and the general tenor is to avoid any further  trouble. We can hear the rhythmic patter of cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, come on... come on --  Let's clear the area. -- Come on,  let's clear this place... Keep cool.  Everybody keep cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bock elbows his way through the throng as it drifts towar the doors to...

dialogues.speaker: THE HOSPITAL, ENTRANCE PLAZA. DAY
dialogues.text: ...and goes through the gathering police. A mobile TV cam crew and a few reporters are hurrying up through the gate from First Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: FIRST AVENUE. DAY
dialogues.text: The Reverend Drummond stands, a solitary human island, am the shrill ROAR of the city. The protesters protest endle CHANTING, SHOUTING. Absolutely no one pays any attention the gaunt, doctor-clad sixty-year-old man standing on an  island. Except, of course, for Bock, who must pause to wait for a red light. Bock hustles through the traffic to where Drum stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
